text: Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers: Proposed Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembJed. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services. The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest. Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in: (i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia; (ii) higher domestic air fares. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Free, Mr Fry, Mr Les Johnson, Mr Les MCMahon, Mr Morris and Mr Scott. Petitions received. Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Title: HEALTH FUNDING
text: I refer the Minister for Health to his firm statement following the Health Ministers conference on Friday, 8 May, when he said: I went in there with a Cabinet policy as my position. I believe the Commonwealth's position is a fair and reasonable one and I believe the States will understand that. I refer the Minister also to his statement last night that the reason for handing over an additional $16m to Queensland was: . . . the basis of the Commonwealth's appreciation of the Queensland position. Does this really mean that, after months of work and the wealth of statistics produced by the Jamison report, he did not appreciate Queensland's position last Friday but did appreciate it, to the extent of $16m, by the following Tuesday?

Speaker: Mr MACKELLAR
Title: HEALTH FUNDING
text: As the House will know, there was a meeting of Health Ministers in Canberra on Friday. The Government had announced its policy on hospital funding. Aspects of hospital funding had been discussed in the Premiers Conference earlier in the week and the Prime Minister at that conference had suggested that further discussion should take place at the Health Ministers conference. I listened to what the States had to say at the Health Ministers conference. They put a particular point of view. I believe that the Commonwealth's basic philosophy and the thrust of its policy are fair and reasonable and the Commonwealth has not diverted from that view. I reported back to Cabinet yesterday morning and Cabinet discussed the matter. The results of that Cabinet discussion have been made public. The basis of the States' concern was that the assessment of potential revenue made by the Commonwealth was in fact not correct. Of course, this would have an impact upon the level of funding which would be divided up among the States in the coming year. There was really only one way in which the statement as to which was the correct assessment could be judged and that was on the actual result. The Commonwealth has decided, very reasonably in my view, that the for Children's Services will States and the Commonwealth will come together towards the end of the next financial year and review the actual results of the imposition of charges and collection of revenue. If necessary, adjustments will be made. By that stage the relativities review which the Grants Commission will be required to carry out will be available not only to the States but also to the Commonwealth. The States have been invited to make a contribution towards the terms of reference for that Grants Commission inquiry. In all these circumstances I think this is a very reasonable way for the Commonwealth to behave in relation to aspects of concern expressed by the States. The basic thrust of the Government's policy remains utterly in place. decision and the announced NA NA

Speaker: Mr JULL
Title: AND UNITED KINGDOM
text: I direct my question to the Minister for Transport. Because of my ongoing interest, I refer the Minister to Press reports this morning that a new air fare agreement has been reached between Australia and the United Kingdom and that a system of deregulation will now be introduced on that international route. I ask the Minister: Does the deregulation apply only to fares? Will there be further access for other international airlines on the route? Will there at last be some reduction for the long-suffering fare-paying public on that route?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: AND UNITED KINGDOM
text: The Press reports did not accurately reflect the outcome of discussions with the United Kingdom. I think I should inform the honourable gentleman and the House of the outcome of discussions that have taken place between the United Kingdom and Australia over the last few days. The Australian and United Kingdom negotiating teams met last week in London. They reached agreement on an Australian proposal that country of origin fares arrangements be introduced between Australia and the United Kingdom. The Australian proposal was developed in my discussions with the board of Qantas Airways Ltd over an extended period. Country of origin arrangements have been in place between Australia and the United States of America for some years now and they have worked well. The agreement with the United Kingdom represents an extension of this approach in the light of experience and in response to changes in the international aviation environment. The agreement does not represent complete deregulation. Arrangements for the filing of new fares by Australian and British carriers and for disapproval of fares filings still remain, but only in exceptional circumstances will filings by those carriers for their services be disapproved. The arrangements allow flexibility for the airlines to respond promptly to changed market circumstances. Existing fare arrangements with other countries remain unchanged at present. Changes to existing fares and conditions between Australia and the United Kingdom were also agreed on by the delegations for consideration by governments. Most important will be the introduction of a new excursion stopover fare priced between the existing APEX fare and the Excursion fare. This is a long overdue introduction of a new fare regime. The new proposals would place Association of South East Asian Nations airline'S on an equal footing with Qantas Airways Ltd and British Airways in that they would have common opportunities to participate in the carriage of traffic on all available fare types. In discussions with the United Kingdom, Australia had regard to its obligation to consult with ASEAN countries. ASEAN views have been taken into account in formulating the new fare arrangements. Yesterday, the Chairman of the ASEAN committee on transportation and communications was informed by the leader of the Australian negotiating team of the changes agreed between Australia and the United Kingdom. Advice is being passed separately to individual ASEAN governments.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Title: AND UNITED KINGDOM
text: Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I wish to ask two questions. First of all, is this a question without notice? Secondly, Mr Speaker, you have given a ruling time and time again that Ministers should be brief in their replies. The Minister for Transport persistently takes a long time iIi his replies. I ask you to give us on this a fair go and to ask the Minister to shorten his reply.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: AND UNITED KINGDOM
text: There is no point of order. However, I calJ upon the Minister to bring his answer to a conclusion.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: AND UNITED KINGDOM
text: In conclusion, Qantas will be meeting with ASEAN airlines later this week to discuss the changed fare arrangements and details of their implementation. The report contained in a newspaper this morning was quite incorrect and I think the House needed to be informed of the actual situation. NA

Speaker: Mrs CHILD
Title: HEALTH FUNDING
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. I refer him to the assessments made by the various State Health Ministers as to why the amounts of money they will receive under the new funding scheme are incorrect in comparative and absolute terms. Is it a fact that these errors arise because: Firstly, Queensland's bed costs are lower than those of other States; secondly, Victoria's offer is wrong because its funds, on a population basis, are lower than those for other States; thirdly, Tasmanian funding was based on an incorrect assessment, on the Commonwealth's part, of cost-sharing in the previous year; fourthly, for Western Australia the Commonwealth had overestimated the additional revenue to be gained; and, fifthly, South Australia saw the hospital charges increase as unrealistic? Can the Minister state whether these assumptions are incorrect and, if not, why he will not delay the changes and hold meaningful discussions with the States?

Speaker: Mr MACKELLAR
Title: HEALTH FUNDING
text: The assumptions made by the Commonwealth are based on figures supplied. by the States. I made it quite plain in my replies to State Ministers on Friday that· I was very happy for officials of the Commonwealth Department of Health to discuss with State officials individual questions which they may have to put forward. The fact of the matter is that the Commonwealth has announced its policy to move towards the inclusion of funding in this area in the general taxsharing arrangements. Those arrangements will have a transitional period while, as I have already stated, the Grants Commission looks at relativities and, of course, again as has been stated, the Commonwealth consults with the States as to the outturn results of the imposition of charges. I say again that the only way in which assumptions can be tested is to put the proposals into place. The consultations which will take place towards the end of the next financial year will enable both the side Commonwealth and the States to have a realistic appraisal of the actual results of the imposition of . hospital charges. Speaker: Dr EVERINGHAM
Title: HEALTH FUNDING
text: I ask the Minister for Health: With the exception of Queensland, does he agree with the State Health Ministers' assessment of the Commonwealth Government's health funding offer as 'unrealistic, arbitrary and dangerously unfair to the people of Australia'? Has the Government said in effect to the States that the Australian federation, with regard to health funding, now consists of decisions made in Canberra which are not negotiable in any sense of that word as understood by the States? In the interests of cooperative federalism, will he be as flexible in discussions with the other States as he was with Queensland and will he table calculations on which the Government bases the expected takings by each State from proposed means-tested charges for standard hospital beds, as referred to by the honourable member for Henty?

Speaker: Mr MACKELLAR
Title: HEALTH FUNDING
text: The answer to the first question is no; the answer to the second question is no; and the answer to the third question is that the Government has demonstrated its capacity and its willingness to consult with all the States, not just anyone of them. The answer to the fourth question is no. NA

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Title: AGE AND SERVICE PENSIONS
text: Will the Prime Minister give an assurance that age and service pensions will continue to be made payable to women when they attain the age of 60 years and that it was never under consideration by the Government to vary that situation?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: AGE AND SERVICE PENSIONS
text: This matter has not been under the consideration of the Government. Because it had been raised in other forums, I not unnaturally consulted with my colleague the Minister for Social Security to see whether he had it in contemplation to put any proposals before the Government. It is not in his contemplation; it is not one of the matters on his desk. I think we need to understand that these payments have been made on an historic basis, because of a way of life to which many people have grown accustomed and which they have been led to expect. It would be rather unkind and unnecessary to upset those arrangements and the expectations that have come out of them. If patterns change some years in the future, so be it. When we have a circumstance in which many people qualify either for an age pension or in some cases for a widow's pension, if those pensions did not exist those people would merely qualify for the unemployment benefit. There would then be no financial saving in that, but a social change would be forced on people which [personally would regard as most unfortunate. The issue is not in contemplation so far as the Government is concerned. NA

Speaker: Mr HUMPHREYS
Title: HEALTH FUNDING
text: l direct my question to the Prime Minister. Did the Minister for Health bring the proposal for $16m to be provided to Queensland for health assistance before Cabinet or was it put forward to Cabinet by the Prime Minister?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: HEALTH FUNDING
text: These matters were put forward to Cabinet by the Minister for Health as a result of discussions. I think that it would be a very odd circumstance indeed if honourable members of this House expected the Minister for Health of the Commonwealth to go through a day's discussions and other bilateral discussions with Ministers for Health or Treasurers of various States and be prepared to ignore those discussions in their totality and take no notice whatsoever of what any of the States might have said. What was put to Cabinet was as a result of discussion on matters that the Minister thought reasonable and the Cabinet, in its judgment, thought to be reasonable. NA

Speaker: Mr DOBIE
Title: MIDDLE EAST
text: -I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to reports in this morning's media that tensions are growing at an alarming and urgent rate between the government of Israel's Prime Minister Begin and Syria's President Hafez Assad. I ask the Minister whether he is in a position to advise the House as to what actions he has taken to a--ertain the true position and how it will affect Australia's interests in the Middle East. In view of the concern shown by the Government at the outbreak of the Iraqi-Iranian war, can we anticipate a statement to the House on the subject of difficulties which could arise not only for the war battered people of Lebanon but also because of 'the strategic wall of Syrian-Soviet friendship and cooperation' for the well-being of the whole area of the Middle East?

Speaker: Mr STREET
Title: MIDDLE EAST
text: I am sure that all members of this House will be concerned about the increase in tension in Lebanon particularly as a result of conflict between Syria and Israel. The subject of the unhappy recent experiences of the country of Lebanon were recently a matter of comment in this House. So far as the most recent events in that country are concerned, the Australian Government has asked the Australian mission in the United Nations to convey to the Secretary General of the United Nations our great concern at the potentially explosive situation which is developing there and which could affect not only the stability of the region but also stability throughout the world. We have asked our mission to make clear to the President of the Security Council our concern and to urge on all parties involved the need for common sense and restraint at this particularly difficult time. We have further said that any initiatives which the President of the Security Council feels he can take in this respect would have our support. I understand that there is little or no prospect at the moment of a United Nations peacekeeping force being introduced to cover the whole of Lebanon because such a force would require a request from the Lebanese Government as well as a resolution from the Se-. curity Council of the United Nations. In respect of that possible development and others in the area, the Government is watching the matter closely and will take what opportunities it can to reduce tensions in the area. Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: DISALLOWED QUESTION
text: Order! The honourable member's question is out of order.

Speaker: Mr IAN CAMERON
Title: DISALLOWED QUESTION
text: My question is directed to the Treasurer. In the light of his having deferred most financial decisions until the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System brings down its report, why does the Treasurer not defer any decision on the possible mergers of Australian banks until then, especially now that there are reports that the Bank of New South Wales wishes to merge with the National Bank of Australasia Ltd with, I believe, disastrous consequences to all Australians?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: DISALLOWED QUESTION
text: In reply to the honourable member for Maranoa I point out that it is not true, as his question implies, that this Government has deferred all financial decisions until receiving the Campbell report. It is correct that a number of possible changes to the structure of our financial system have been put off until we receive that report. But even in that context a number of quite significant decisions have been made in advance of the report, including in particular the decision taken last December to deregulate the then existing controls on borrowing rates by Australian banks. 1 do not believe that it would be a satisfactory discharge of my responsibilities under the Banking Act, in the face of the mergers which are currently being contemplated, to say that the matter was altogether too difficult for the Government and that it ought to be put off until after the receipt of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry. I think that obligations are cast upon the Government-myself in particular-under the existing provisions of the Banking Act and I think that it would be an inadequate discharge of those responsibilities to say that the matter should be put off until we receive the report of the Camphell Committee oflnquiry. Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: FOREIGN INVESTMENT
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer to the near record monthly private capital inflow for April disclosed today and the fact that 99 per cent of foreign investment approvals for the first half of 1980-81 were for takeovers of existing enterprises. Is it a fact that the huge volume and direction of this private capital inflow is blowing to pieces the Government's money supply target of 9 per cent to 11 per cent, is inherently inflationary and is applying substantial pressures for further interest rate increases? Is it a fact also that it is responsible for a large scale alienation of Australian ownership and control of established Australian industry? Furthermore, is it a fact that it is forcing significant revaluations of the Australian dollar and accordingly creating serious price disadvantages on comBANKING petitive export markets for exports of Australian manufactured goods and farm products? Does he acknowledge that these effects are contrary to the best interests of Australian farm and manufacturing industries, stable economic management, and the promotion of the national interest? Will he therefore take immediate steps to haul back this damaging flood of foreign investment into a more manageable flow?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: FOREIGN INVESTMENT
text: The Leader of the Opposition has asked a very long and very important question. I will try to give it the detailed response that it merits. It is true that the most recent balance of payments figures have indicated a very large increase in the volume of private capital coming into Australia. It is true that that inflow contains a very high element of portfolio investment. It is equally true that all of the reasons for that very large increase can be a matter of conjecture. It has something to do with the existing interest rate differentials between United States domestic interest rates and Australian interest rates. I do not accept the description that the Leader of the Opposition places upon this situation; that is, that it is blowing the Government's money supply projections to pieces. The most recent indications for the 12 months to, I think, March show that the growth in M3 is about 11. 7 per cent. That is up by about 0.7 per cent on the previous month's figures but, as the honourable gentleman knows from his earlier experiences, these figures can fluctuate very wildly from month to month. It would be a fairly brave person who tried to put a precise figure upon the final outcome at this stage of the year because at this time of the year the external account is always the wild card so far as the money supply outcome is concerned. It appears that there was a stronger seasonal element in the most recent balance of payments figures than is normally the case. This is partly due to the fact that provisional tax payments are larger this year-by an estimated 30 per centthan was the case a year ago and that they are being paid earlier. Some of the information from the money markets suggests that arrangements for tax payments have been made earlier than last year and that more funds have been brought in from overseas for those purposes. As the honourable gentleman knows, all of the matters which bear upon the external account are interrelated and the conduct of exchange rate poli-y has an impact upon international competitlveness. Equally, of course, international competitiveness is a reflection of domestic success in controlling prices. To the extent that the external account is conducted in a way that reduces and does not increase the level of inflation, that has a beneficial effect on our international competitiveness. Speaker: Mr EWEN CAMERON
Title: FOREIGN INVESTMENT
text: Is the Minister for Transport aware of a news report on the Australian Broadcasting Commission this morning outlining the Government's plans for Trans-Australia Airlines'? Can the Minister clarify to this House the Government's intentions'?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: FOREIGN INVESTMENT
text: As I announced in this House previously the Government intends to establish TAA as a public company. The Government will initially hold 100 per cent of the shares in the new public company. However, the Government will commission private consultants to examine the practicalities of selling shares in TAA including how this might be done in the light of our domestic air policy. The consultants will report also upon what measures should be taken to ensure independent ownership of Australia's trunk airlines. The consultants will be asked to report within about 12 months. I emphasise however that the Government has made no deci-ion to seli any part of TAA to the private sector. The Government will await the advice of the consultants before taking a decision on the matter. In the meantime, TAA will be established as a public company with 100 per cent Commonwealth ownership. However, the memorandum and articles of association will not inhibit the sale of TAA or part thereof to the private sector. Of course, the report will provide the Government with the benefit of having the best advice possible before taking a decision on the matter. We will also be freeing TAA from the restraints imposed upon a statutory authority. Mr Morris- Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. As this matter is one of major importance to the Australian people it demands that there be a statement from the Minister so that the Government can explain its view. Question Time should not be so flagrantly abused. The matter should be aired properly, not in this furtive way ofleaking statements.

Speaker: Mr NIXON
Title: SALE OF WHEAT

Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: FOR COMMONWEALTH PUBLIC
text: Darling Downs--Minister for Housing and Construction)--by leaveFollowing a request from the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure conducted an examination of alternative delivery systems for Commonwealth public works. The Expenditure Committee's report was tabled in this House last year. It contained conclusions and recommendations that addressed the need for flexibility, efficiency and accountability in relation to public works. The Committee concluded that: (1) The choice of a particular delivery system for a particular project has to be made in the context of the circumstances of that project and hence is a matter for the judgment of administrators. (2) The choice of delivery system for a project should remain with the organisation that has prime carriage for the planning, design and construction of public works. (3) It is not practical to formulate guidelines for the selection of a particular delivery system. ( 4) Since a government department or agency is responsible for the efficient administration of public works, that department or agency should always have overriding authority over project management companies and others on these works. CLAIM I am pleased to inform the House that the Government fully endorses these conclusions. The report went on to make three recommendations: (1) The Department of Housing and Construction either include in its annual report or supply the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for inclusion in that Committee's general reports information relating to tender price, costs of rise and fall contract clauses, design alterations and other costs, and the particular delivery system used for each completed major capital work. (2) The Department of Housing and Construction expedite the preparation of design and supervision costs for major public works and publish these costs in its annual WORKS reports. (3) The Department of Housing and Construction assess the advantages and disadvantages of contractual project management and use this delivery system when circumstances permit its use. I am also pleased to inform the House that the Government accepts these recommendations. Action is in hand to publish this information on tender price and other costs in the Department of Housing· and Construction's 1980-81 annual report. It will cover major works completed during that year and will cover all projects referred to the Public Works Committee and those exempted from that Committee's scrutiny on the grounc,ls of expediency. Works exempted on security grounds will not be covered. The Government has taken and will be taking other steps to enhance the efficiency, flexibility and accountability of the Commonwealth's works programs, particularly in relation to the works of statutory authorities. Amendments to the Public Works Committee Act will extend that Committee's scrutiny to cover many statutory authorities. The Government has also introduced new public works procedures aimed at achieving more consistency and better value for money from the Commonwealth's works expenditures. The Department of Housing and Construction is working on the detailed arrangements to apply these procedures. These procedures will result in consistent conditions of contract for all Commonwealth works, including works of all statutory authorities. Those statutory authorities which are or will be subject to the Public Works Committee scrutiny under the proposed amendments will be required to consult with the Department of Housing and Construction on design and cost aspects to ensure that soundly based and consistent estimates of cost are prepared and presented to the Government and the Public Works Committee. The recommendations made by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, in conjunction with other initiatives the Government is taking, will in no small measure help to ensure that the Commonwealth receives value for money from its construction expenditures and that the Parliament, the Government and the public are better informed about those expenditures. Finally, I would like to congratulate and thank the Committee for this report. I commend the report to the House. I present the following paper. Alternative Delivery Systems for Commonwealth Public Works-Ministerial statement, 13 May 1981. Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed: That the House take note of the paper.

Speaker: Mr UREN

text: Reid) (3.12)--The ministerial statement on Commonwealth public works arose out of the request by the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure which conducted an examination of alternative delivery systems by Commonwealth public works. Of course, we know that the Expenditure Committee report was tabled in the House last year. I wish to briefly make a few comments in regard to the report. The three recommendations accepted by the Government are welcome in particular, recommendation (1) which deals with information relating to tender prices. As the Minister for Housing and Construction ( Mr MCVeigh) knows, and would have heard prior to taking over his ministry, there was a great deal of criticism during the last Parliament in relation to the tender prices for the purchase of a computer for his own Department and the manner in which those tenders were carried out. We know that as a result of pressure, both externally and later internally, within his Department the lowest tender and even the tender with the greatest Australian component in the project were not chosen. Therefore, it is important that tender prices be made public and that a section of this Parliament should be able to examine such tenders. Recommendation (3) deals with contractual projects of management. For instance, in examhiing the day labour force under the control of the Department of Housing and Construction it can be seen that the number of people employed has actually fallen from 6,592 in 1977-78 to 4,995 in 1978-79. The tendering process was so bad that I believe something was very wrong. I think that there was collusion between certain sections of the bureaucracy and the IBM company to allow that computer to come through. Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: FINANCE
text: Parramatta) (3.20)-I wish to take a couple of minutes to comment on some aspects of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. Perhaps more importantly, I express my pleasure that a report of one of the House of Representatives standing committees, of which I had the pleasure to be the Deputy Chairman in the last Parliament, has been accepted by the Government. I think that it is fairly honest to say that some of these committees find great frustration inasmuch as they put an enormous amount of work into formulating a report which they believe to be honest, accurate and forthright, and then find that the report is largely ignored by the Government. So it is pleasant to find that the Minister for Housing and Construction ( Mr MCVeigh) and the Government have seen fit to accept fully the recommendations made by the Expenditure Committee in this report which is entitled 'An Examination of Alternative Delivery Systems for Commonwealth Public Works'. I express my pleasure also on behalf of the members of the Subcommittee. By some strange quirk of fate I am the last remaining vestige of that Sub-committee. My colleagues, Mr Kevin Cairns and Mr Ken Aldred, unfortunately for them, have passed into early retirement. I am sure that, even in their retirement, they will find some satisfaction in that the hard and diligent work which they and other members of the Committee put into this report has been accepted, honoured and put into practice by the Government. On their behalf, may I express pleasure at that event but, more importantly, that the honest and difficult work of committees of the House is not altogether ignored. That represents a watershed. Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Title: HOSPITAL FUNDING
text: Bonython) (3.24)-There should, after the farcical events of the last four days, be very little reason to argue the iIlconceived nature of the Government's hospital funding proposals. What was non-negotiable on Friday has become highly negotiable, at least for one of the States, by Tuesday. Indeed one might now describe the new federalism as simply a surrender to the noisest and most obstreperous of the little Australians, Joh Bjelke-Petersen, without regard for the interests of the other States or for the logic of the agreement, if there be logic to it, which was presented to the Health Ministers last Friday. However, it is not simply the flaws in execution of the agreement that we on this side of the House are attacking. We believe there are far deeper flaws than the farcical events of the last few days regarding the hospital funding agreement. We believe the fundamental principles of those funding proposals are wrong. It is, first of all, simply a reactionary step in late twentieth century Australia to abandon a national government role in determing priorities for the hospital sector. We believe that it is simply a backward step to abdicate at this point in the development of the nation responsibilities of the Commonwealth Government towards the hospital sector. Although the Minister for Health e Mr MaCKellar) often in very vague ways clothes his arguments for his new policies in the report of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, it is quite clear that the Jamison Commission opposed the proposal to hand back hopital funding to the States through general purpose grants. This is what the Commission had to say: The Commission's view is that the existence of some form of identified funding for health ally accepted as a means of health care is available across State boundaries for the Australian population. Although transitionally there may be some identification, it is clearly and explicitly the intention of the Government simply to include hospital funding in the general purpose grants to the States so that it would be unidentified, untied and quite contrary to the beliefs of the Jamison Commission. The ideal of that Commission was that there should be a rough equality of services across State boundaries. It did not believe that this could be achieved unless there was a significant contribution by the Commonwealth Government. The ideal of a Commonwealth contribution to maintain a rough equality of services across State boundaries was supported by most of the national health agencies in this country. That ideal is now being undermined by the present policies to which the Federal Government is committed. Indeed, the Federal Government's position is basically an abdication of responsibility for the public hospital sector. I have argued before that this will ultimately lead to a fragmentation of service provision. For example, it is already apparent that quite different means test proposals will apply in most of the States. Queensland has indicated quite clearly that a means test will not be introduced into the free hospital system which it has had for a generation. New South Wales and Tasmania are both looking at applying more generous means tests than those propounded by the Commonwealth Government, which has a very narrow definition of need. No doubt some of the other States will simply follow the Commonwealth plan and have a fairly narrow definition of 'socially disadvantaged'. Quite ditTerent sets of means tests will apply in some States. In one State at least there probably will be no means test at all. This will lead to quite different health cover provisions in each of the States; the health cover needs in each State will be different. We are then left with questions concerning not only the variety of health covers but also the mobility of Australians: Will Australians need to adjust their health cover as they move from State to State? The whole of t-- implications of this abdication of responsi?II.lty are really quite foreign and quite antagonIStiC to the development of society in the late 20th century. When honourable members on this side of the House make these points they are often subjected to quite false reasoning from honourable members opposite. Members of the Australian Labor Party services has come to be generensuring that a high standard of are not suggesting that a rigid uniformity should be imposed by the Commonwealth on the States. We are suggesting that the Commonwealth should participate with the States in the determination of priorities for public hospitals in this country. It should do so not just on one occasion; there should be regular participation by the Commonwealth Government with the States in determi.ning national priorities for public hospitals in thiS country. We are not suggesting that the participation should be practised as it is presently being practised by the Minister; that is, simply at the crude level of squeezing funds and letting the States pick up the burdens. We are suggesting that there should be genuine co-operative federalism in the health field, not the unco-operative federalism that has characterised this federation in recent weeks. Indeed, the whole evolution of the present hospital package is a classic example of unco-operative federalism. There has been no effective give and take. There has been no genuine consultation between the Commonwealth Government and the States on the Jamison proposals. In order to support the statement. I have just made. I will quote the statement made by all the State Health Ministers: It states: We observe that we have never been consulted in the real sense of the word and at no time prior to its recent decision has the Commonwealth indicated any clear intention to the States. Unless the Government is going to say that all these State Health Ministers are simply money grabbers, that they have simply got no care or concern for health issues, then that statement is a very clear repudiation of the whole uncooperative approach that has been adopted by the Government in response to this matter. Indeed, I think it is true to argue that there has been more consultation with powerful vested interests-the private health funds and the Australian Medical Association-than there has been with the States. I am confident that the Government and the Minister have talked more with those vested interests who have done very well out of this package than th-::y have with the States. Indeed, in many ways the package was designed to serve the interests of the vested interests in the health sector rather than to serve either the interests of the States or the people of this country. Our first major objection to those proposals-these inefficient and ill conceived proposals-is that we oppose the abdication of the Australian Government from any responsibility in the public hospital sector. The second principle that we oppose is the imposition of the means test at the point of service delivery. The Government, of course, is now attempting to ensure that a means test is imposed by the financial sanctions that it is using against the States. I will come back to that point. The Minister often clothes his rhetoric in the words of Jamison. The Jamison report is a conservative report, very sympathetic to the values of Government. Yet this report referred to the means test. First of all, the report echoes the views of the Minister on the principle of the user pays, so it is very much sympathetic with his line. The report states: Because the Commission believes that those able to pay should do so, and that they should be encouraged to do so through insurance, it gave much consideration to the reintroduction of a means test for free access to both inpatient and outpatient services at public hospitals. In dDing so, it recDgnised: that sickness Dften generates CDstS other than medical costs - for example, cost of the breadwinner's income fDr part or all of the term of incapacity; that hospital administrators who gave evidence to the Commission were almost unanimous in their opposition to such a proposal; that collection of debts has been a difficulty in It considered variDus propDsals test. It found majDr objections to all of them. The best it could suggest was possibly an informal income test without sanctions. That is certainly not the view of the Government. The Jamison committee looked at it and discovered, therefore, that not only did most hospital administrators oppose it, not only did it create enormous inefficiencies in relation to debts, but also it recognised, of course, that with sickness there are a whole lot of after costs besides simply the medical bills. Therefore the Jamison committee opposed the kind of rigorous means test which this Government is trying to impose on the States. Of course, if the Government is successful it will create in the hospital sector a two-tier system. We will have the public sector primarily catering for the poor, the disadvantaged, and also, of course, for the high cost technology activities. All the straight forward, high profit surgery will be channelled into the private sector, which, of course, has received increased subsidies for those very types of surgical activities which the Jamison committee pointed out were one of the major cost problems in this society-the excess elective surgery in Australian society. Yet, this Government, supposedly worried about costs, provides a specific subsidy to encourage that activity in the private hospitals. All of the double talk of the Minister cannot cover that up. Indeed, on this issue of the means test we have really had the most extraordinary double talk from the Minister. During the election campaign, when of course, it might have worried the voters if they were told that in six months time the Government was going to endeavour to impose on the public hospitals a means test, the Minister was very strong on this point. He stated: . . . there was absolutely no truth in the statement that the Government was planning to restrict patients' free access tD public hospitals by reimpDsing a means test fDr hDspital care. With the need to win the election only six months ago the electors were assured that no means test would be imposed. Six months later the Government is going all out to compel the States to impose a means test. But when questioned on this the Minister said: A decisiDn as to whether a means test will be impDsed for access to public hospitals in entirely a matter for the States concerned. That does not have anything to do with the Minister. That is no explanation whatsoever. If one had the past. read the Minister's statement of a fortnight ago, one would see that it clearly implied that unless for formalising such a means the States imposed a means test they would have financial sanctions imposed upon them. The Minister deliberately set out-whatever he said yesterday-to compel the States to impose a means test. Let me just show how this is to be done. First of all, each of the States has had a very significant cutback in funds. I ask the permission of the Minister to incorporate a table in Hansard to try to suggest some of these fund cuts that have been made.

Title: TO STATES UNDER NEW HOSPITAL ARRANGEMENTS

Speaker: Mr MACKELLAR
Title: TO STATES UNDER NEW HOSPITAL ARRANGEMENTS
text: Warringah-Minister for Health) (3.39)-The Government rejects the Opposition's politically motivated claims that the new funding arrangements for State health services will adversely affect State and personal finances or will lead to a decline in hospital standards. I believe, the Government believes, that the Government's position on future funding levels is a fair and reasonable one. It could, in fact-the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) wlW led for the Opposition has not acknowledged this-lead to the States having additional resources available to them next year because of the cushioning factor which has been built into the arrangements over this transitional period. The Government's position will, we believe, lead also to increased efficiency in costly stitutions, such as public hospitals. I notice that the honourable gentleman did not spend any time at all on the efficiency of public hospitals-the most expensive component of the health care delivery system. He did not attach any weight to the question of increasing the efficiency of the administration of public hospitals. I am sure that this is something quite foreign to persons of a big spending nature, such as those exemplified by members of the Opposition. It is typical of the approach taken by a socialist Labor government. It is typical that the questions of cost, administrative leanness and administrative efficiency are completely left aside. Without in any way jeopardising the level of care now available in public hospitals, the arrangements we will put in place will be an advantage to all taxpayers because they take into account the necessity for administrative efficiency. The Opposition's track record demonstrates beyond any doubt whatsoever that it is not concerned about efficiency or ensuring that taxpayers are protected by government action and that we receive the greatest value possible for each dollar spent on health care. As I have said on many occasions in this Housand outside, the fundamental goal of the Government in the health area is that all Australians should have proper access to high quality health care at a cost that the individual and the community can afford. I remind the House that health care delivery is a very expensive proposition. All developed nations are finding the containment of health costs one of the most difficult aspects of their general administration. As part of the containment of costs the Government believes that welfare assistance in the form of so-called free public hospitals should be made available only to those in genuine need, those people whom the honourable member for Bonython has said are defined narrowly by the Commonwealth Government. I will say more about that in a moment. The Government believes equally that those who cannot be viewed as needy should contribute towards the cost of the health services available to them. That aspect of the Government's attitude seems to have escaped the attention of the honourable gentleman opposite. I was pleased to see that even the Queensland Minister for Health agreed with this position. He said recently: It is recognised that some people abuse the present free public hospital system. Therefore, the individual who uses the free outpatients or the free hospital system, who can afford to pay, needs to examine his own conscience on this matter. The Queensland Minister for Health, who has very recently made something of a feature of the Queensland free hospital system, in line with his in- Premier, has publicly stated that a person who can afford to pay and does not pay, in his words, 'needs to examine his own conscience on this matter'. The Government also firmly believes that there should be a number of inbuilt checks and balances in the health care delivery system to minimise unnecessary use and abuse of the system. This is because over-use and abuse of the health care delivery system unnecessarily increase the cost of financing that system for the community. These beliefs are fundamental to the Government's health policy. Socialised systems for the provision of health care have been allowed to continue without those necessary checks and balances. They have resulted in a continuing increase in the utilisation of services and the drain on taxpayers' funds. The new funding arrangements for State health services embody the principles that I have outlined. We will continue to ensure that special arrangements operate to protect those in genuine need. The honourable member for Bonython said that the Commonwealth has abdicated its responsibilities in the public health area, particularly in relation to hospitals. That is simply not true. What the Government has done is to ensure that those in genuine need are protected by allowing them free access to public hospitals. We require the States to provide free access for eligible pensioners and their dependents plus those who are defined by the Commonwealth as disadvantaged. The honourable member for Bonython said that disadvantaged people are narrowly defined. The arrangements will protect about three million people in this country. Over 20 per cent of the population will be protected. How that category can be put forward as being narrowly defined I cannot conceive. We believe that all other people should be required to contribute towards the high cost of public hospital accommodation and treatment. In calculating the level of funds that should be provided to the States next financial year for their health services, we have subtracted from the funds they would otherwise have received a reasonable share of the additional revenue they could be expected to receive if those people not in genuine need were required to contribute towards the cost of their accommodation and treatment and if more realistic bed day charges were introduced. In view of the misinformation that has been put about in relation to the Commonwealth estimates of the revenue raising capacity of the States in the public hospitals area, I will spell out this afternoon the manner in which the level of funds for State health services in 1981-82 was calculated. As I advised the House last month, in calculating these grants the base figure adopted was the amount to be provided to the States and the Northern Territory for public hospitals, the general community health program and the school dental scheme, plus an amount to maintain the real worth of the year's figure. I emphasise that the base figure for each State is the same real level of funds it is to receive this financial year for the three health programs to which I have just referred. From this base figure we have subtracted only 60 per cent of each State's assessed capacity to increase its revenue through the public hospital system if, amongst other things, the existing bed day charges of $50 and $75 for shared ward and private room accommodation respectively were increased to $80 and $110 and an out-patient charge of $15 per service was applied. The remaining 40 per cent is free to the States. It is additional revenue which will be available to the States to spend in whatever area they wish. In calculating the potential revenues for each State's public hospital system, the Commonwealth has assumed that only half of public hospital patients will be paying patients. That is a reasonable assumption given that the other measures announced to the House last month will see a much larger percentage of the population taking out health insurance. Obviously, in those States in which close to 50 per cent of patients pay for their beds at the present time, more than half will pay when the new arrangements come into effect. We have also assumed that charges will be made for only one-third of existing out-patient services. Again, this is a very reasonable, if not a conservative, assumption. We have assumed that people covered by third party and workers compensation will be charged at the full average cost which, again, is fair. I repeat that the Government believes that the assumed level of charges and the other assumptions involved in calculating each State's revenue raising capacity are fair and reasonable. Hospital bed day charges at $80 a day are especially reasonable when we remember that the figure is equal to the amount one would have to pay in a good hotel these days. Of course the hotel charge would not include three meals and expensive attendant care which is provided in a hospital. An out-patient charge of $15 per service is also fair and reasonable when we remember that the charge for a standard consultation with a general practitioner is $11.80 in New South Wales and that outpatients receive pharmaceutical items free of charge whereas a person who receives a prescription from a private doctor has to pay at least an additional $2.75. As a number of honourable members will know, the States have questioned the Commonwealth's assumptions stating that they are unrealistic. The honourable member for Bonython has drawn attention to this in his statement to the House today. Only experience will prove whether the claims of the States or the Commonwealth are correct. The Government has now decided that an assessment should be made towards the end of the next financial year of each State's capacity to increase revenue with adjustments being made to the level of funds provided if that is considered appropriate. Again, I believe that this is a fair and reasonable approach to a problem caused by the States' saying on the one hand that they do not believe that the assumptions the Commonwealth has made are correct and on the other hand the Commonwealth's saying that it believes that they are correct provided they are based on the figures provided by the States. There they are based on the figures provided by the States. There is only one way in which the matter can be realistically sorted out and that is to look at the actual results of the implementation of the policy. If the estimates are grossly wrong and adjustments are necessary, the Commonwealth stands ready to make those adjustments. Concern has also been expressed by Queensland about the loss of funds it would have sustained in 1981-82 under the Commonwealth's original proposition. rt was argued that Queensland is a special case as it is the only State with a free public hospital system. In considering the Queensland Government's arguments the Commonwealth was particularly mindful of the view presented by the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals that any changes to the public hospital system should be gradual and that sudden changes could be disruptive. The Jamison report stated: . . . sharp, sweeping changes can be disruptive and impractical . . . much can be gained from continued small measures, rather than from sweeping structural change. The Government also took into account the fact that only about 40 per cent of the Queensland population has hospital insurance, while the national figure is about 55 per cent. It also into account the fact that a much smaller percentthe age of patients in Queensland's public hospitals are paying patients, whereas in States, such as Victoria and New South Wales, well over 40 per cent of patients are already paying patients. Therefore, in the case of Queensland I think it questionable whether our assumption that 50 per cent of public hospitals patients would be paying patients, is reasonable. In other words, we have looked at the situation in Queensland and we have made an adjustment for it. These were the argumaintaining ments that were put to the Commonwealth and I believe it is only proper that the Government should review its position in the light of them. I must say that I find it difficult situation in which if one does not react to any proposition, one is regarded as stubborn, but one does react, one is regarded as weak. It seems that a Minister or a government with the capacity to review realistically propositions put by States or individuals and make judgments is in a no win situation either from the point of view of the position or the media. But the Government is prewill pared and has been prepared, and I as a Minister have been prepared, to look at the situations which have been put to 1I).e by State Ministers. has already been announced, the Government has made its statement clear in relation to the individservices ual circumstances. As honourable members will meet be aware, the Commonwealth has agreed to introduce, for one year only, a cushioning factor in level of funds to be provided to Queensland in 1981-82 by providing an aditional $16m to that State. I remind the House that the Government has decided that the Grants Commission should, as a matter of urgency, be asked to look among States in order to remove inequities and to provide incentives for States to correct inefficiencold, cies. The Government, therefore, recognises that there could be inequities in relation to the allofrom cation of funds between States in the health area and that action may be needed to correct this. necessary, that action will be taken, and I have asked the State Health Ministers to make sublogic missions on possible terms of reference to the Grants Commission as soon as possible. Again, think that this demonstrates a reasonable apdraw proach to a difficult problem. We have heard much today and over the past few days of the need to provide additional funds to the states for their public hospitals. Regrettably we have heard very little about the need to operefficient. ate efficient public hospital systems and the siderable waste and inefficiency in those systems highlighted by the Jamison inquiry. For too long took States have been more concerned about having Commonwealth underwrite their inefficient public hospital systems instead of taking appropriate action to ensure that their public hospitals operate efficiently. The new funding arrangements under the Government's new health policy is are designed to promote efficiency by requiring the States to take up their full constitutional responsibility for the provision of health services. This will ensure that taxpayers get the greatest value possible for each health care dollar spent in the high quality health care system we all enjoy, and it is a high quality health care system. I am sure that all taxpayers will welcome this and will expect the States to take up this to understand a challenge. We have also heard much today about how the if Government's new health policy will adversely affect the community. Let me remind the House that under our policy about three million people-those in genuine need-wi11 be entitled to free public hospital and medical services. Much Ophas been made of the fact that all other people be required to pay for the health services they receive or take out health insurance. Let me again say that exponents of this view fail to acknowlAs edge that those who are not in genuine need will be required only to contribute towards the health they receive. They will not be required to the full cost of those services, a cost that in .many cases is well in excess of the charge actually the levied. The actual cost of a public hospital bed, for example, is now close to $200 a day because considerable subsidisation is provided by the Government to bring the cost of health services within the reach of the community and to ensure that all people have access to health insurance at at relativities that reasonable cost.

Speaker: Mrs DARLING
Title: TO STATES UNDER NEW HOSPITAL ARRANGEMENTS
text: Lilley) (3.54)-A number of hard facts have been covered up by a lot of the hot air that is being generated in statements the Government side of the House regarding the most recent health mess. The statements just If made by the Minister for Health ( Mr MACKellar) have done nothing to alleviate this mess. The ill in the statement that the States have not been running their hospital schemes efficiently I and therefore the Federal Government will withentirely not only from funding but also from any position in which it could inject some efficiency into the hospitals, is unbelievable. We now see that the Government believes that by standing back the hospitals will magically become The Minister has also indulged in very conselective quoting. He quoted from the report of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals to back his very spurious arguments. But, in fact, the Jamison report stated that the Queensland hospital scheme is the most efficient scheme and has the most efficient administration in Australia. Yet it is this very scheme which the Government is moving to dismantle. The Minister also quoted the Queensland State Health Minister, Mr Brian Austin, again very selectively. The Minister quoted Mr Austin as saying, in the Telegraph of Wednesday, 22 April: . . . the individual who uses free hospital system, who can afford to pay, needs to examine his own conscience on this matter. He completely neglected to quote further. Mr Austin went on to say: It has been stated by the Commonwealth that the states will be forced to means test at public hospitals. This statement would indicate that the Commonwealth has absolutely no idea of what's involved in the lic hospital system. I find it entirely objectionable that different little facts are taken out of context to try to pull the wool over the eyes of the Australian public. Many facts have been hidden. I would like to speak on behalf of ordinary Australians who have been affected by this Government's complete neglect of a decent health insurance system. The Australian Labor Party is the only party which is concerned with health costs and which supports a health insurance scheme which meets the needs of ordinary Australians. The Labor members of this House are the only members who support the retention of Queensland's free hospital scheme, which the Jamison report-the report on which this Government is basing its action-describes as the most efficient system in Australia. I would like to point out these further facts: Prior to the introduction of Medibank, Queensland's free hospital system was on its last legs; it was on the point of collapse and ?ould not have gone on. I speak from close expenence, my father having been the shadow Minister for Health in the Queensland Parliament at the time. When Medibank was introduced the Government injected the necessary funds into the scheme it, as honourable members have heard, has beway, come the most efficient in Australia. In its original form Medibank was also very acceptable to the electorate. In my electorate of Lilley doctors afraid before the introduction of Medibank that everything would fall into shambles. After its troduction, those doctors actually supported Medibank because it was much more efficient and it gave proper health treatment to everyone withservices out the doctors having long lists of bad debts. This Government, instead of being honest dropping the scheme, as contrary to its private teeth. enterprise philosophy, has worked consistently to put health insurance out of the reach of middle and lower income earners. It has succeeded. There are hundreds and thousands of people who now cannot afford medical care or medical health insurance. People in Queensland have been forced into out-patient departments or they have had to stay home and go without the treatment they need. In recent months the out-patient departments in hospitals have been overflowing. With this scenario as a background, this Government the free out-patients or the now moves to withdraw funding not only from Queensland but also [rom all the States, as positive proof of its lack of interest in any health insurance scheme. It is particularly ironic that the Government's two week-old health policy, suffering symptoms of terminal prevarication, should come unstuck at running and operation of a pub· the very time that the Government has never been more unhealthy. This indecisive, disintegrating Government, showing symptoms of its last dying days in office, is thrashing about looking desperately for some direction for its policies. The fact that Cabinet fidgeted and fussed over hospital funding arrangements for four months indicates its divisiveness and the lack of leadership at the helm. These indications that Government policy was drifting aimlessly were confirmed by the extraordinary events of the past two weeks and particularly the events of yesterday. It is typical of the inefficiency continually displayed in the Government's administration of health services. As my colleague the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) pointed out, the philosophy linking the Government's health policy and its hospital arrangements is that the sick pay. The user pays principle does not apply; the sick pay. We all know which economic group in society is the most prone to sickness and hospitalisation: it is those who are too poor to afford stable and nourishing diets and those who cannot afford regular medical check-ups which enable diagnosis and treatment of illness in its early stages. The Queensland Minister for Health said reand cently that, if the Federal Government had its Albert Schweitzer's inscription outside his African jungle hospital would have read: 'Here, in whatever hour you come, you will find the light were and help of human kindness, if you have got enough to pay'. The words of the Federal Minister infor Health two weeks ago were: 'If you are willing to pay for yourselves'. This is the Government's motto and its approach to the provision of health to the public. It is the old survival of the fittest and wealthiest principle, a social Darwinist and approach to health. The poor pay through the Yesterday marked the anniversary of Florence Nightingale's birthday. I am sure she must be turning in her grave. In the health field this Government has replaced the sorts of principles that Florence Nightingale represented with the cold hard doctrines of Ayn Rand. This Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser), who beats the drum of co-operative federalism and who, until a couple of weeks ago, boasted that Federal-State relations had never been better, did not even have the nerve to consult the States on the new Commonwealth provisions for health services. Right up until the Minister's statement was made in this House, State Health Ministers were guessing about the form in which the Federal Government's assistance would be provided, whether it would be by absorption in general revenue grants or by block grants as recommended in the Jamison report. The Prime Minister and his Cabinet cronies ride roughshod over the States in the same fashion as they steamroll Ministers who do not completely toe the Fraser line, in the same way that they contemptuously ignore the view of their own increasingly restless and rebellious Government backbench and in the very same way that they handle the business of disseminating information about the process of Government policy-making by selective leaking to the media. We are told that the devolution of responsibility and blame for the country's system of health will supposedly grant greater freedom to the States because hospital assistance will now be absorbed in the category of general revenue grants and the States will have greater flexibility and discretion in the distribution of federal money. What they do not say is that there will be substantially less federal money to go around. Besides that, anything that offers the Government of Mr Bjelke-Pctersen greater dictatorial power, greater manoeuvrability and greater leverage, must raise fears even in the stoutest hearts. I have little sympathy for the predicament of the Queensland Government in this matter. After all, it continually supports the Prime Minister's now very publicised manic obsession to withdraw government services, devolve powers to the States and to leave people generally to fend for themselves. Now that the Federal Government extends that principle to the Queensland Government so that it must fend for itself, it is screaming blue murder. For many years, Queensland had to pay a financial penalty to a Federal Liberal Party Government for providing this service. Two weeks ago, the Minister, while calling for deinstitutionalisation with one breath, introduced, with the next breath, measures designed to kill individual associations and to fortify institutionalisation. I refer to the lumping together of a number of services such as the school dental scheme. Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER C Mr Millar)Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr HODGES
Title: TO STATES UNDER NEW HOSPITAL ARRANGEMENTS
text: Petrie) (4.6)-This is the second week in a row that the Opposition's spokesman on health (Dr Blewett) has raised a matter of public importance which relates to health. This, coupled with questions that have been asked, has, quite frankly, allowed for an almost ad nauseam debate. One wonders just what impression he is making. It is my view he is making no impression at all. As a matter of fact, it is my view that the present Opposition is sick and needs medical attention and, indeed, hospitalisation. It is the Australian Press at the moment which plays the role of the opposition to this Government. It is about time that this Opposition got off its backside and started to do something about providing a reasonable Opposition to this Government. It is the Press, not the Opposition, that is the real opposition to this Government. The honourable member for Lilley ( Mrs Darling) spoke about the ordinary people of this nation. I remind her that I also represent ordinary people in my electorate, as, indeed, do all honourable members of this House. She talks in terms of providing everything free. I emphasise that 'free' is in inverted commas. Nothing is free in this nation; everything has to be paid for. She has spoken about the poor people, the pensioners and the disadvantaged. I would like her to come with me on some occasions to let her see how those people attend bingo games, use the Totalisator Agency Board and go to hotels. Mr John Brown-Turn it up; you don't believe that. MI' HODGES-The honourable member for Parramatta can come with me to my electorate and I will go with him to his. It amazes me that honourable members on the other side of the House claim that these people do not have any money to provide the priority items in life such as clothing, food and health but they do have enough money for other matters. It is true. There are many such people in my electorate. All honourable members have them in their electorates. I am concerned about those people. But I am also concerned to see that there is some self-help involved in their Jives. The honourable member for Bonython mentioned the Government's non-negotiable position at the Commonwealth-State Health Ministers conference which was held last Friday. He indicated that proposals discussed at that conference were changed this week. This is utter nonsense. The Minister for Health ( Mr MACKellar) has not, in any way, departed from the basic policy that was announced by the Government in this House two weeks ago. Of course the States are unhappy. I have never known the States, since Federation, to be happy with any decision made by a government in relation to funding. Let us consider the $16m .that has been given to Queensland. Queensland does have a special position. At the present time, in Queensland, 20 per cent of the total number of beds in hospitals are· paid beds. Under the formula of the present health arrangements, that figure would be increased to 50 per cent. If this occurred in the first year of the new funding arrangements, it would create certain difficulties for that State. That is an unrealistic position that had to be rectified; hence, of course, the extra assistance that has been given to Queensland. Let us have a look at the wording of the matter of public importance which we are now debating. It states: The detrimental impact on State and personal finances-The Government, this financial year, will collect about $34.5 billion. Whether this is collected by way of personal income tax, or by way of indirect taxes such as excise, sales or company tax, it is the duty of this Government to ensure that those collected dollars are spent efficiently. It is not the Government's money; it is the people's money. The money does not belong to Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. The money does not belong to Mr Howard. The money belongs to the people. (Quorum formed). It is obvious that the Opposition does not like what it hears and therefore it is taking up some of my time. The States, under Fraser federalism, have the capacity to raise their own funds. They can impose their own taxes their own charges if they want to. We have over the years a certain erosion of that capacity raise funds. It is my view that if they want money for hospitals they have the capacity raise that money and spend it on those hospitals set their own priorities. The Labor Opposition stands for bigger governsome ment and bigger taxation. In actual fact it is that it wants this Government to increase taxes that there will be more money in the tax pool payout to the States for whatever purpose. It is my view and the view of this Government that, as far as possible, the earnings of individuals be left to those individuals to spend and that, far as possible, governments should keep their hands out of the pockets of individuals. This contrary to the statement made by member for Bonython when he talked about the detrimental impact on personal finances. Indeed, the situation is to the contrary. In actual fact the Government's policy is beneficial to the individual. The Labor Party supports open-ended arrangements. We saw so many of them in the three years of the Whitlam Government. We have seen repeated statements from the honourable member for Bonython and the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Hayden)-they are well documented-that they want to see a return to Medibank. The honourable member for Bonython nods approval. That sort of statement should be promulgated as widely and as strongly as possible throughout the nation because the people have not forgotten the three years between 1972 and 1975 when this policy was in operation. That policy was disastrous then and it will be disastrous if Labor ever comes to power and institutes it. The cost incurred by governments on behalf of the people in the health field and in other fields must be identifiable. People must be responsible for their own affairs. All accounts, whether they be hospital accounts, accounts for diagnostic services or whatever, should show clearly what costs are involved. Indeed, even if the accounts are not actually paid by the individual because that individual falls into the disadvantaged category-he may be a pensioner or whatever-the costs ought to be set out clearly so that the individual has some idea of what those costs are. Indeed, those persons within our institutions who order these services also ought to be aware of the nature of the costs. We have seen the general thrust of the health policies that the Commonwealth introduced a few and weeks ago supported by most of the States. seen Queensland, Victoria, Western Australia and to South Australia support the general thrust of the more policy. They are unhappy with the quantity of to money they have received but they support the or actual policy involved. The assessment of the hospital payments that has been the subject of debate over the last three or four days has saying been made on the data supplied by the States so themselves. It has not been based on Commonto wealth figures; it has been based on information that has been provided by the States. Of course, as the Minister for Health has stated in the House on should more than one occasion, the Commonwealth as Grants Commission will look at the situation in relation to the relativities between States and is assess whether any State ought to be better the honourable treated in the future.

(b) at the lack of effective accountability of the National Companies and Securities Commission to either the Government or Parliament of the Commonwealth, or to any other single elected Government or Parliament, and (c) that despite the inordinate delay in introducing the legislation, the Parliament of the Commonwealth has not been given an opportunity elIectively to scrutinise this bill and associated bills and will not be able effectively to determine company law in the future under the Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme; (2) calls upon the Government in the event of the breakdown for any reason of the scheme, of which the Bill is a part, immediately to proceed to the introduction of Commonwealth legislation for the national regulation of companies; NA (3) notes that this Bill places uniformity before reform in deference to powerful vested interest groups and represents a retreat to the lowest common denominator standard of company law; (4) calls upon the Government to expedite the establishment of an Accounting Standards Review Board, and (5) calls upon the Government immediately to pursue a fundamental reform of company law, including: (a) the abolition of the category of "exempt proprietary company" and the privileges associated with it; (b) the provision of statutory directions and powers to the National Companies and Securities Commission and the courts to look behind the corporate entity in appropriate circumstances, to ascertain those who control it or hold shares in it, and, having regard to the purpose of the creation of the corporate entity and the manner of its control, to affix personal liability and adjudicate personal rights do so; (c) the extension of the powers of inspection of the National Companies and Securities Commission to ensure the fullest to books; (d) the amendment of any provision which enables questionable practices to be hidden by means of legal professional privilege; (e) the requirement for all companies to raise and maintain a prescribed minimum nominal and paid up capital; (f) rationalisation of the cumbersome provisions in respect of company names on the basis of single nationwide registration; (g) a requirement that companies disclose all donations for political purposes; (h) a requirement that dividends be paid only from the genuine profits of a company; (i) full review of the provisions relating to fund raising and prospectuses to require independent valuation of assets exchanged for issued shares; Ul reform of the provisions relating to companies financing dealings in their own shares, including the removal of the exemption given ied directors; (k) provision for a higher required standard of competence, care and diligence for directors and officers of companies; (1) a requirement that more frequent accounts be lodged by companies listed on the Stock Exchanges; (m) in order to protect creditors and to assist the prevention of tax avoidance, the imposition of stringent disclosure requirements upon companies acting as trustees of trading trusts, trustees and the accounts of the relevant. trusts, and the imposition of heavy penalties for non-compliance; (n) full disclosure to the public of the beneficial ownership of all shares in companies; (0) published accounts to include full details of each director's and officer's remuneration and right of inspection for employees and shareholders of director's service contracts; (p) adequate remedies for oppressive conduct, including extension of the concept of oppression to single and anticipated acts unfairly prejudicial to a shareholder; and provision of further means such as a 'Shareholders' Tribunal' to protect the interests of minority shareholders, and (q) complete reform of the winding up provisions, including greater protection for unsecured creditors, following a reference on insolvency to the Australian Law Reform Commission".

The general notion that such private companies should have financial based perhaps on the idea that individual proprietors do not want their employees, or dare I are say the tax man, let alone anyone else, to know how rich they are is outmoded and unjustified in a society where pay scales in virtually all salaried employment are easily ascertainable.
