Speaker: Mr MOUNTFORD
Title: PAIRS
text: Banks) (4.57)-I wish to refer also to the matter of exempt proprietary companies which is dealt with in clause 5 of the Companies Bill. Page 5 of the Bill states: 'exempt proprietary company' means a proprietary company(a) no share in which is, (6) of this section, deemed to be owned by a public company; and (b) no member of which is a public company; In other words, all proprietary companies would be exempt if they were not wholly or partially owned by a public company. In other words, they need not appoint an auditor and need not file a copy of their accounts along with their annual returns as long as they either operate as an unlimited company or have their accounts audited. I believe that there should not be any provision for exempt proprietary companies. From the point of view of trading creditors, exempt proprietary companies are bad. Trading creditors, particularly those small firms which deal with companies, have no guarantee that the company is in a sound financial situation if they cannot see its accounts or if those accounts are not audited. In addition, I believe that employees of private companies should be able to view the finances of those companies in an audited return. Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (5.0)-In our overriding amendment we have a clause which refers to clause 7 in the Companies Bill. That amendment states that we call upon the Government immediately to pursue a fundamental reform of the company law, including the provision of statutory powers to the courts to enable the lifting of the corporate veil in appropriate circumstances, including that whereby a holding and subsidiary company effectively operates as a unit and where a private company acts as a trustee for a trading trust. In backing up that amendment which we have moved I would like to make a few remarks about trading trusts. As I said, we believe that trading trusts, having small private companies as trustees, should be abolished, not left substantially unregulated with only a vague promise of future regulation, as has happened in the second draft of the Companies Bill. Trading trusts provide a classic instance of a tail, that is, tax avoidance by a private business, wagging a dog, that is, carrying on business activity with a proper legal structure. by virtue of sub-sections (5) and Over the last 100 years or more-not that any of us would remember that; not even you, Mr Deputy Chairman-the Companies Act and the accompanying case laws have built up an elaborate set of rules to which business enterprises must adhere if they are to have such privileges as limited liability. Accounting rules, standards of skill, care and honesty for directors, personal liability of officers when a business is carried on fraudulently-these, along with many other legal protections for existing and potential shareholders, creditors and other interested parties are all based on the premise that the company in question owns and runs the business in its own right. If, instead, a small, grossly under-capitalised company is permitted to hold the business on trust, the value of these protections is, at best, doubtful and, at worse, negligible. In a manner which is wholly confusing to outsiders, the normal roles associated with the company's form are changed around. As an example, the recipients of surplus profits become trust beneficiaries instead of shareholders, although the trustee company itself is a shareholder. Management of the business is formally vested not in the directors but in the company itself in its capacity as trustee and so on. This is merely because tax planners saw that the company-trust combination might produce tax advantages for their clients. There is no reason why Parliament should give in and allow many years of work in developing a sophisticated system of company law to be undermined. To allow only private individuals or properly established large-scale trust corporations to manage businesses on trust, as is the case in various parts of Canada, would both preserve the effectiveness of company law and reduce the range of tax fiddles available to private business. We are unsophisticated enough in the Opposition to believe that companies should be set up to enable business to be conducted properly, to enable the shareholders to be properly protected, to enable creditors who are dealing with a company to be properly protected also and not merely to have an opportunity to deceive people by having what is known as the corporate veil pulled across the eyes of those people who seek to do business with that company. The Opposition's proposal that the National Companies and Securities Commission and the courts be directed and empowered to look behind the corporate entity, to ascertain those who control it or who hold shares in it, relates to the process known in common law as lifting the corporate veil. Some people euphemistically refer to the corporate veil as the purdah used by capitalist Muslims, but in this case we refer to it as that veil of secrecy which is placed across companies to prevent proper scrutiny of that company and all that it stands for. Mr Dobie-Is that your business theology now?

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Yes. We believe that this process of lifting the corporate veil is rendered necessary by the long established principle that the company, as a legal entity separate from its shareholders and director, is an artificial legal personality capable of perpetual succession and capable of sueing and being sued. The liability of the company to pay its debts extends to the assets of the company, but the individual shareholder is not liable beyond the amount unpaid on his shares. The misuse of the corporate personality in the shape of $2 companies is very well known. In fact, the offices of the Corporate Affairs Commission are littered with the number of $2 companies that have crashed, to the detriment of employees, creditors and shareholders. The immunity of shareholders and, in the absence of fraud, directors from liability for contractual or tortious wrongs upon the part of a company is in striking contrast to the joint and several liabilities of the partners in the partnership. The courts will not, except in certain limited circumstances, lift the corporate veil unless there is a specific legislatwith ive direction to do so. The Opposition requests that these powers be granted and, indeed, that the NCSC and the courts be directed to look to those who should properly be liable in cases where the corporate vehicle is simply used as a shield against liability. I reiterate what I started to say in the first place in relation to this clause and that is that we would like the provision of statutory powers given to the courts to enable the lifting of the corporate veil in appropriate circumstances so that companies can be made accountable both to their creditors, their shareholders and their employees.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Recent1y, if Press reports are an indication, there has been a considerable interest in the trust device to carryon conventional business practices. By using this device the provisions of the Companies Act may be avoided, no matter how many beneficiaries of the trust there are. There is no doubt as to why that device was deliberately deleted from the legislation. We all know that. There has been a contentious decision of the English Court of Appeal that unit holders, as a unit trust, do not associate together for the purpose of gain. That has been the generally accepted position. The Court of Appeal in reaching that decision reversed the decision of Jessell at first instance. The trust device in question was a mere subterfuge for the evasion of companies legislation; it still is. The trustees in reality were directors and the unit holders were really members or shareholders. The modern unit trust vests the trust property in trustees but the property is managed by an independent management company and not by the trustees. I think we ought to understand that. The management company, therefore, fulfils the role normally played by directors. Surely the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) does not dispute that concept. Since the Smith v. Anderson case, trusts involving more than 20 unit holders or beneficiaries have frequently been used to operate investment schemes in companies securities and land. Such fixed or flexible tusts are regulated, or were, by Part IV, Division 5, of the old Companies Act, if units of interests are offered to the public. Until recently, there has been no indication that trusts more than 20 beneficiaries would be used to carryon conventional business activities. I would like that explained. Such trusts should be subject to the same regulations as companies. Why not? I would like an answer from the Minister as to why they should not be. This is necessary if we are going to protect beneficiaries and creditors of trusts. I hope that the honourable member for North Sydney ( Mr Spender) perhaps will get up and we can have a little bit of a debate on the matter. It is recommended that beneficiaries under a trust should be deemed to be associated together for the purposes of the provisions of the Companies Act. This would mean that trusts with 20 or more beneficiaries, established for the purposes of gain, would have to be registered as corporations. The Minister ought think about that. The Ministerial Council ought to think about it. Dealing with clause 267 (1) (a), I should like some observations from my kind friend the honourable member for North Sydney. Creditors who deal with management companies may be misled into believing that the property used by a management company belongs to the management company. I will repeat that so that we can debate it. Creditors who deal with management companies may be misled into believing that the property used by a management company belongs to the management company and so will be available to creditors in satisfaction of their claims. We agree on that. That is the position. The reality is simply that the property belongs to beneficiaries of the trust and is not available to creditors. Hence it is important for the legislation to require all companies whose business is to manage property not belonging to them to disclose to creditors that the property apparently in their control and ownership in fact is held in trust. Is anybody prepared to dispute that? I would not think so. Disclosure should be made, firstly, in all business correspondence with creditors and, secondly, in the company's audited annual accounts filed with the Corporate Affairs Commission. At present most companies acting as trading trustees fall within the classification of exempt proprietary companies. As a consequence, those companies do not have to file audited annual accounts. So we have to contend with both-exempt proprietary companies and trading trusts. I make two simple observations: Not only does this structure-corporate structure, if you likeavoid being bound by the provisions of the Companies Act but also, I think it is true to say equally that it is a scheme for tax avoidance. It is an indictment of the Ministerial Council that there is not adequate provision to cover trading trusts, and I support my friend the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown).

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: PAIRS
text: North Sydney) (5.13)-Let me say, since I have been invited to do so, that from this side of the Committee I do not think we would say that one forecloses the question of the introduction of provisions concerning trading trusts. As I understand the position, the matter is under examination. Some very complex questions are raised by the disclosure provisions originally included, and I will put one of those to the Committee. We can have a trust company whose task it is simply to administer trusts. That is a perfectly legitimate exercise. Let us assume in favour of the trust company I am talking about that there is no tax avoidance, no tax evasion, and that it is a perfectly straightforward exercise. One of the problems it then faces when it deals in the open market, for example when buying shares on behalf of a number of different trusts, is the complexity of saying on each occasion: 'We will buy 200 shares for Trust Y, 200 shares for Trust Z, 200 shares for the next trust', and so on. The imposition of the disclosure requirements could be highly technical and not easy to comply with, and I speak of the requirements as they appeared in the April exposureHonourable members have referred to the use of trusts for tax avoidance purposes. Certainly that takes place, there is no doubt about that, and there is no doubt that companies acting as trustees are sometimes used for the purposes of tax avoidance. But that does not say that we should introduce legislation which may pose many more problems than it cures. I put it to the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi) that, after all, he is not looking at a novel situation. Trusts have been around for a long time, and if we move companies to one side, as it were, and provide that there shall be, as he has said, the lifting of the corporate veil in all cases, then the true tax avoiders will simply find another means of going about it, which I assume would be to have an ordinary trust without a company holding the position of trustee. I certainly agree that it is a matter that is worthwhile looking at, and it should be looked at further, but I have reservations about the provisions as they originally existed in the April exposure draft.

Speaker: Mr MOUNTFORD
Title: PAIRS
text: Banks) (5.15)-The Opposition does not believe that the clause dealing with subsidiaries, holding companies and related corporations affords sufficient protection to the public in the way it is presently drafted. The definition of subsidiaries and holding companies is crucial to other clauses of the Bill. The Bill does not seem to recognise that in a great many cases holding and subsidiary companies act as a unit and not as separate entities. Creditors can therefore be disadvantaged since a holding company need take no steps to bailout the creditors of its insolvent subsidiary. The subsidiary's employees, of course could be similarly affected. Insofar as trusts are concerned, and I believe they are covered by clauses 164 to 167, might I say that over the last 100 years or more the companies Acts and accompanying case law have built up an elaborate set of rules to which business enterprises must adhere if they are to have such privileges as limited liability. Accounting rules, standards of skill, care and honesty of directors, personalliability of officers when a business is carried on fraudulently, along with many other legal protections for existing and potential shareholders, creditors and other interested parties, are all based on the premise that the company in question owns and runs its business in its own right. If, instead, a small, grossly undercapitalised company is permitted to hold the business on trust, the value of these protections is at best doubtful, at worse negligible. In a manner which is wholly confusing to outsiders, the normal roles associated with the company formed are changed around. For example, the recipients of surplus profits become trust beneficiaries instead of shareholders, although the company itself has shareholders, management of the business is formally vested not in the directors but in the company itself in its capacity as trustee, and so on, merely because tax planners saw that the company-trust combination might produce tax advantages for their clients. I worked in private enterprise for many years prior to coming into this House and I know that many holding companies have subsidiary companies for the purpose of manipulating those subsidiary companies, particularly in high risk areas. They will form subsidiary companies in high risk areas so that, if those companies go bad, there is no loss to the shareholders. There is certainly a loss to creditors and there is certainly a loss to employees. I have seen this happen. Nothing whatsoever happens to the shareholders in the holding company. They get off scot free, but the creditors and employees are left holding the bag. For that reason, I do not think that this clause has been correctly drafted and J believe that the area covering trusts should be completely struck out.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (5. I 9)-To wind up the Opposition's objections to this clause, we believe that the defmition of subsidiary and holding companies is crucial to many other clauses of the Bill. For example, in regard to accounts, group accounts must be prepared for subsidiaries, and that is a reference to clauses 269 to 272. However, the Bill goes only part of the way towards dealing with the reality that holding and subsidiary companies act as a unit and are not separate entities. Creditors can be disadvantaged since a holding company need take no steps to bail out the creditors of its insolvent subsidiary-that is a vital attribute as far as we are concerned--and employees can also suffer for the same reason. I instance the case of Massey Ferguson, a company which crashed in Australia a few years ago, which was a subsidiary of a Canadian holding company. The Canadian company made no effort at all to bailout the Australian subsidiary and left creditors, employees, et cetera, lamenting. So we would strongly urge the Minister to see that some reforms can be made in this area in future through the Ministerial Council so that this whole subject of subsidies, holding companies, trust companies, et cetera, is ironed out and made much more specific.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (5.20)- The amendments are not acceptable to the Government. I do not accept the proposition that subsidiary companies are necessarily set up to defraud creditors. I spoke last night on the question of creditors and I mentioned then that I do not understand how people can be left holding the bag, as it were, in the case of a subsidiary company if they have made due inquiry. If someone trades in a risk position, having failed to make due inquiry, I do not know how that person can complain about the Companies Act. Clause agreed to. Clauses 8 to 11-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 12 (Power of Commission to require production of books).

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (5.22) Clause 12 relates to the power of the National Companies and Securities Commission to require the production of books of companies. We have some reservations about this clause. We feel that the Commisson is prevented from getting books in certain circumstances under the provisions of this Bill. For example, we think that the Commission should be able to obtain access to books to enable it to formulate recommendations for law reform. Clause 12 (1) (a) contains a rather pleasant phrase. It states: Other than the power of the Commission under sub-section 6 (3) of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act. The Commission is prevented from obtaining access to books by that sub-clause. We have no doubt that this clause was inserted after the 1980 exposure draft at the behest of business interests wanting to maximise privacy. I guess that in practice the provision is not likely to have any great effect but it raises the point as to how much privacy public companies are entitled to. That runs counter to the Labor Party's argument that requires maximum public accountability. Clauses 12 (2) (a) and 12 (3) (a) require that the reason for the examination of the books be specified. The intention is obviously to prevent fishing by the Commission. But we feel that this is not justified in the light of public accountability. In our view it is necessary to distinguish between civil liberties like privacy and the liberties of those engaged in business. I take issue with the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) on this matter-I say in passing that on this side of the House we have considerable respect for his integrity-and disagree violently with his view as to how business should be done. We do not think that doing business with a company under the many guises that companies have and under the many corporate forms that companies may take should be like being involved in a lottery. Certainly there is a risk involved in doing business with some types of companies. The old caveat emptor rule remains paramount. But if a propel; national companies law existed, a lot of the risk that is taken both by creditors and shareholders would be eliminated. That is all we are asking for in a national companies law, that proper accountability be made paramount so that companies can not only be seen to be doing business respectably and be doing it respectably but also that they pay their fair share of the tax burden.

Speaker: Mr MOUNTFORD
Title: PAIRS
text: Banks) (5.24)-1 agree with my colleague the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown) that there should be greater access by the Commission to companies' books so that more public accountability exists. I also mention at this stage that I did not say in my earlier remarks that all subsidiary companies set out to take the public in or, indeed, to take creditors in. I said that some of them are set up for that purpose, particularly in high risk areas. I believe that if the Commission is given the proper power it deserves under this clause, it would do away with a lot of those cases involving failed companies. If the Commission was of the opinion that a company was going bad, or likely to go bad, it could pull the books in, make the company more accountable to the public and at least stop some businesses folding up. I believe that particularly in the New South Wales Companies Act there are proper provisions for this. Certainly there is more power in that Act than there is in this legislation. As my colleague the honourable member for Parramatta mentioned earlier, this Bill has been brought together by taking the very least from all of the State Acts; so there is a lowest common denominator. I believe that the Commonwealth should have used its powers more and introduced a national Companies Act rather than this emasculated legislation which we now have. As far as clause 12 is concerned, I believe that insufficient powers have been given to the Commission and I believe that they should so be given.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: PAIRS
text: North Sydney) (S.2S)-ln answer to what has been said by honourable members, I say that the provision contained in clause 12 gives very wide powers for the inspection of books where a contravention or a failurc to comply with a provision of a relevant Act is thought to have taken place. Other circumstances are set out in clause 12 which are, if my recollection is correct, wider than those in existing laws. For my part, I think that businessmen are just as entitled to privacy as ordinary citizens. There should be no greater right of inspection than what is presently conferred by clause 12. Under that clause and in conjunction with the provisions concerning special investigations if it is in the public interest to investigate the affairs of the company, the widest of investigations can be carried out. Witnesses can be examined and books can be inspected and impounded. Taking those provisions together, there are perfectly adequate mechanisms in this Act for the inspection of books. I simply cannot understand how it can be said that to widen the inspection powers in clause 12 would in some way assist law reform. Law reform stems from the examination of a whole series of events. It does not flow from fishing around in the affairs of private businessmen. Clause agreed to. Clauses 13 to IS-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 16 (Privilege).

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (5.29)We are still dealing with inspections. The part of the second reading amendment which we moved called upon the Government to reform this area. We were talking of: the amendment of any provision which enables questionable practices to be hidden by means of legal professional privilege. I have no doubt that the honourable member for North Sydney ( Mr Spender) will take umbrage at what accusations we mayor may not level against the legal profession. But it seems to us that this is the first of a number of protections given to legal professional privilege. We feel that the clout of the legal profession has led to the insertion of these protections. We also feel that it is an invitation for evasion of the legislations because under this provision questionable transactions need simply be channelled through an unethical lawyer. I must say that the Commission can require the name and address of the person to whom or by whom a supposedly privileged communication is made. But we still feel that it is an invitation to evade the provisions of this part of the legislation which calls for proper accountability. Under those circumstances we question it quite severely. We call on the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to remove that clause and to revert to the exposure draft in 1980 which did not include it.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: PAIRS
text: North Sydney) (5.31)-First of all, lawyers are always a convenient target for attack. But let us put that to one side. Secondly, it is very important that we should remember that the rights which are being protected are the rights of a person to obtain advice. When one looks at clause 16 one sees that there is protection against privileged communications. These are communications which fall within a very narrow compass such as communications made for the purposes of obtaining legal advice to assist, for example, in a case which is coming up or which has been brought against one. Because of the narrowness of the protection, it has to be bona fide legal advice which has been sought, a privileged communication, within the narrow compass that the law has laid down, but an exceedingly necessary compass because we should all be entitled to obtain legal advice; and that includes companies and even company directors.

Speaker: Mr MOUNTFORD
Title: PAIRS
text: Banks) (5.34)-1 oppose this clause also. I do not see that there is any need for legal people to be given any special attention. I note that bankers are not given the same protection; nor are accountants. I think accountants and members of the legal profession in the past and also at present are making a mockery out of certain provisions that this Government has introduced, particularly those provisions that apply to tax evasion. 1 cannot see why there should be any privilege whatsoever applying to any person, whether he be a legal person, a banker or, indeed, an accountant. From memory, I think that no such privilege is granted under the New South Wales Companies Act. 1 do not think any should be granted under this Bill. Clause agreed to. Clauses 17 to 32-by leave--taken together, and agreed to. Clauses 33 to 37-by leave-taken together.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Hawker) (5.36)-1 want to deal with the question of minimum paid up capital, which 1 raised last night. As I understand it, the courts have always taken the view that a company's share capital should apply only for the purposes of business. You do not think that is right, Mr Minister? Mr Moore-I did not say a word.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: J am pleased that we have unanimity about something. Mr Moore-I only looked.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: I am sorry. Creditors are supposed to be able to rely on a company having a particular issued or paid up share capital and that that capital will remain undiminished by any expenditure other than that on legitimate business. Unfortunately for creditors and for, perhaps, shareholders, the provisions in this Bill will be singularly ineffective in making the share capital concept an effective barrier against losses. There is nothing in this Bill to strengthen that. The English position and that applying in this country stands in marked contrast to that applying to countries throughout the European Economic Community. 1 regret to say that the rot set in at a very early stage. The National Limited Liability Act was enacted about 1855. It provided for three basic issues: Minimum share capital of £250 had to be paid in excess of 20 per cent; three-quarters of the company's nominal capital had to be prescribed; and the company had to be wound up if three-quarters of its capital had been lost. The situation has deteriorated a lot since then. Each one of those safeguards has disappeared. They disappeared as early as 1862. They have not been replaced. There is nothing in this Bill to replace them. Other restrictions to protect creditors-that is, the rules that reductions of capital must be approved by the court and dividends must not be paid out of capital-have proved, regrettably, weak in practice. It is an unfortunate fact that, in the United Kingdom and Australia, creditors cannot afford to rely ,on a company's capital. I do not think that anybody in this chamber would disagree with that statement. It is a regrettable fact of the corporate structure in Australia. Few companies that are wound up are able to meet their debts, let alone return any capital to their members. The English Act of 1855 required all companies with limited liability status to have at least £ 250 in minimum share capital. That provision disappeared in 1962. Ever since then it has become possible, as I said the other night, to form a limited liability company with a share capital of seven shares for a par value of about one farthing. We have not changed from that. We have allowed that provision, in Australia, to reach 2c and for public companies 5c. That is a scandal. At least, the 1862 Jenkins Act reported that in principle it would favour a statutory minimum paid up share capital. It further noted that under capitalisation was a major cause of business failure. Nobody denies that. Experience in this country certainly supports that concept. But it declined to recommend the introduction of a minimum paid up capital requirement because it would be relatively easy to evade. I suppose that is true. In particular, it would be difficult to prevent a company from returning its minimum capital to its promoters in exchange for assets by way of loan or by some other way. It is interesting to note that the supposed difficulties with minimum capital requirements have not prevented some European countries from enforcing it. Austria has a minimum paid up capital requirement-MONICA

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: PAIRS
text: How much?

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: It is $US5,500. Does the honourable member want more figures?

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: PAIRS
text: Yes.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: France has a minimum paid up capital requiremen,t of $3,650; the Federal Republic of Germany has a requirement for $7,700; Italy has a requirement for $50. That is marvellous, is it not? Australia is not even on a par with that. Australia's requirement is for a minimum paid up capital of 5c. Sweden has a requirement for $10,500; in Switzerland, it is $7,200. It is interesting that the Netherlands has no prescribed minimum capital; but, if Australia did not have that requirement, perhaps it could apply the provisions that apply in the Netherlands. The Netherlands does have the provision that authorised capital must not be more than five times the issued capital. Furthermore, the Ministry of Justice will not authorise the formation of a company unless it believes that the company's issued capital is appropriate in view of the company's objects and other financial sources. I would settle for that provision. That is far better than the inadequate provisions applying in this legislation. If we look at that panorama, I suppose it can be seen that the minimum capital requirements are the order of the day. In Australia,a minimum paid up capital of perhaps $10,000 would be appropriate for proprietary companies, while $50,000 would be appropriate for public companies. We ought to think about it. These amounts should be reviewed regularly to take account of inflation. I think that existing companies should be required to conform with the requirements within 12 months of the commencement of the legislation. When we consider the high level of liquidations in this country and the devastating effect liquidation has on shareholders and creditors we can see that this is an appalling piece of legislation. I suggest to the Minister that this is one of the matters that ought to rate highly at the next meeting of the Ministerial Council.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (5.40)-1 think that the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi) has fully summed up our reservations about this area. In fact, I think that we probably have stronger reservations about this part of the Bill than we have about any other part of it. That is why our second reading amendment referred to modifying or altering the law so that the raising and the maintenance of a prescribed minimum nominal and paid up capital for all companies became mandatory. 1 noticed with some interest that the honourable member for Hawker suggested what might be the minimum amounts required for Australian companies, and 1 would not argue with that. His suggestion is certainly a long way in advance of 2c and 5c, which I am sure even the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs finds quite ludicrous. Mr Jacobi-He agrees with it; I am sure he does.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Yes, I am sure he does. 1 think the examples which the honourable member for Hawker gave of the minimum paid up capital in other nations should be quite enlightening for us when we look at the sort of companies law under which we battle in Australia. Unfortunately Australian company law has never required a minimum nominal or issued company capital. Of course, that has been used historically to the detriment of creditors and shareholders. One solution, I would suggest, is to require the amount of capital to be included in the name of a company if it is less than a certain amount-for example, Bloggs $100 Pty Ltd-and require so much to be paid up. In European Economic Community countries, particularly the United Kingdom, it is now necessary for public companies to issue shares to a nominal value of not less than the authorised minimum-in the United Kingdom that amount is $50,000-and to receive payment of not less than one-quarter of the nominal value of each issued share. We do not argue that that exact example should be introduced in Australia, but we think that anything that gets us away from the $2 companies would have to be an advancement. We find that to be one of the prime failings 'of this Bill. I am sure the Minister agrees with me ano'the Opposition generally in this respect. I am sure that we have sufficient faith in the Minister to be confident that he will press this matter at the next Ministerial Council meeting notwithstanding all the difficulties of having to obtain agreement from a majority of seven State governments. This would be one area in which he should have a specific look at taking Australia out of the ridiculous situation it is in at the moment where a company can be formed with 2c or 5c capital. This is an abolutely ridiculous situation in 1981.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (5.43)-The Government cannot accept the proposal at the moment. I think that the points made by the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi) and the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown) certainly carry some weight. I am not convinced by the argument that the capitalisations of $5,000, $7,000 and $10,000 held in the countries the honourable member for Hawker mentioned are in themselves guarantees against bankruptcy or that sort of activity. It is really just a matter of form. Other factors go well beyond this. Nevertheless, I think that the comments made by the honourable members are worth noting. Clauses agreed to. Clauses 38 and 39-by leave---taken together, and agreed to. Clauses 40 to 64-by leave--taken together.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (5.45)We are now dealing with one of the cumbersome parts of the Bill. We are calling on the Government to rationalise the cumbersome provisions in respect of company names. It seems to us to be quite ludicrous that we need 24 or 25 clauses in this Bill to cater for the names that companies may give themselves. I point out that the Labor Government's Bill which was rejected in 1974 would have eliminated a great deal of this verbiage and perhaps only four or five clauses would have covered the same area. The procedure for reserving and registering company names, already complicated and expensive, especially when multi-State trading is involved, becomes in fact a legal nightmare under this Bill. A quick glance at the index to the Companies Bill and the section headings in Division 2 of Part III will indicate the enormous number of different procedures for reservation and registration, depending on the precise nature, location and trading intentions of the company in question. Perhaps the most striking example is clause 57, which refers to 'Registration of name of foreign company that has become a recognised company after transfer of incorporation to participating State or Territory'. Surely even my learned legal friend the honourable member for North Sydney ( Mr Spender) could find a simpler way than that mouthful of rationalising that name. A good deal of the complexity is attributable to the numerous related but technically distinct names applicable to the corporate entity. I refer to clause 5 (I), which covers about five or six pages of the Bill and deals with the various types of companies that can be established. More importantly, the opportunity has been lost in this Bill to simplify the company names procedure by enabling companies to make an available search on a national basis and permitting only those names to be registered which are nationally available because such a system would obviate the need to specify the particular States in which registration is desired and would more particularly, if computerised, greatly reduce administrative cost. J would refer that suggestion to the Minister. It just seems to us to be flamboyantly excessive to have 24 or 25 clauses to list the number and types of names that companies might have. Perhaps this is another area in which the Minister might suggest to the Ministerial Council some quick reform. Clauses agreed to. Clauses 65 and 66-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 67 (Powers).

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (5.48)Clause 67 deals with the powers of companies. We would like something to be done about this area. We ask the Committee to agree to our proposals, which would give the Government power to require the disclosure of donations paid for political purposes. Need I say any more? There is a requirement for companies to list donations to charitable causes. Whilst I could never in any of my wildest dreams consider the Liberal Party to be a charitable cause, I would like to think that that power should be extended to make sure that any donation to a political party should be made public, as is the case under United Kingdom law. I would like to be able to pick up the Ansett accounts every year and find there is a donation of $50,000 to the Liberal Party. At least the public would know who supports political parties. If our suggestion were implemented the same thing would apply perhaps to other organisations that contribute to the Australian Labor Party. We have nothing to hide or to fear. If this were done, I think the whole area of companies law would be considered to be more decent. Certainly, it would have a great deal more prestige if these sorts of donations from companies, public or otherwise, were made public. I would hope, perhaps futilely, that the Minister also might suggest this to the Ministerial Council. Clause agreed to. Clauses 68 to 93-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clauses 94 to I 09-by leave-taken together.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (5.50)We are now discussing Part IV of the Bill, prospectuses, securities and charges. The Opposition moved an amendment which called for: . . . full review of the provisions relating to fund-raising and prospectuses to ensure maximum disclosure and to require independent valuation of assets exchanged for issued shares. In supporting the amendment I mention that in October 1970 the Company Law Advisory Committee, better known as the Eggleston Committee, reported to the Standing Committee of the Attorneys-General on control of 'Fund Raising, Share Capital and Debentures'. The detailed report of the Committee contained sections on the protection of investors in relation to fund raising operations, statutory provisions relating to prospectuses and the content of prospectuses. Some of the Committee's recommendations over the years have been implemented but the present Bill involves no significant changes in the prospectus provisions. Once again the opportunity to utilise the deliberations of the only expert committee to look at company law in Australia in the last 20 years has been missed. We feel that this is a deplorable state of affairs. The Opposition is particularly concerned to ensure maximum disclosure to prospective purchasers of shares or debentures and to ensure that the interests of existing shareholders are not prejudiced by the issue of shares for nonpecuniary consideration, for example, in the form of assets. The latter requires a statutory obligation to obtain an independent evaluation. I think that probably there have been bad manifestations of that weakness in the law in the not too distant past. I will not mention all such instances, but the Negri River Corporation share trading was probably a fairly good example of that. I will not say any more on that matter except that the Opposition is not at all happy with the provision regarding prospectuses and the lack of information contained in them. The Opposition requires urgent reform in that area to make sure that investors buying shares in a company are fully protected and fully warned in advance of what they can expect by proper reference to a properly detailed prospectus.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (5.54)-This is one part of the Bill which needs some attention. I am sure that the Ministerial Council will address itself to this matter in the fairly near future. It is a very important part of the capital market. In my view it constitutes the crunch of the matter because the invitation to the public to subscribe is the starting point for investment. Because of that we need to look at the areas not only in terms of shares, prospectuses, the memorandum of offer, the type of share for asset exchange and the type of share options offered to various people from time to time such as employees or particular directors but also in terms of unsecured notes, notes and debentures and the type of debentures offered. Far too often in the past the type of prospectus offered to the public, whilst meeting the technical requirements, certainly did not give the necessary information as to what the issue was for and the real purpose behind it. With valuation, particularly in the area of the acquisition of assets for shares, there is a need for, I think, more certification of value assets and where they really come from. Clauses agreed to. Clauses 110 to 112-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 113 (Return as to allotments):

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Hawker) (5.55)-I wish to discuss two points. The first concerns the closing 'off of the offsetting cash transaction loophole in the provision relating to non-cash consideration of share issue. I think that was recommended by the Eggleston Company Law Advisory Committee but there is no embodiment of that recommendation in this legislation. Mr Moore-That is contained in the general review to which I referred before.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: That is being generally reviewed, is it? I wish to make a passing reference to the United Kingdom Companies Act 1980 which contains a requirement for non-cash considerations for shares to be subject to expert independent valuation. That is the part of which there is an appalling gap in the report of the issuing by company shareholders to the Corporate Affairs Commission. I will not canvass the whole issue to the report which was very competently made to the South Australian Government in 1977. Actually, to be blunt, there was no excuse for the members of the Ministerial Council not to have applied their minds to the issue. The matter was looked at in depth in 1977. I wonder what research has been done in the departments in the respective States, including our own area. In the few. minutes remaining before we suspend the sitting for dinner I will make some reference to the United Kingdom Act. I suggest to the Minister that this is one area that ought to be looked at closely by the Ministerial Council. I will read some brief extracts from sections 24 to 27 of the United Kingdom Companies Act 1980. Subsection (1) of section 24 reads: . . . a public company shall not allot shares as fully or partly paid up . . . otherwise than in cash unless--. This is then set out in paragraph (b) which states: A report with respect to its value has been made to the company by a person appointed by the company-Paragraph (c) states: A copy of the report has been sent to the proposed allottee of the shares. Sub-section (4) states: The valuation and report required by sub-section (1) above shall be made by an independent person . . . who(a) appears to him to have the requisite knowledge and experience to value the consideration; and (b) is not an officer or servant of the company or any other body corporate which is that company's subsidiary or holding company or a subsidiary of that company's holding company or a partner or employer of such an officer or servant; Sub-section (5) states: The independent person's report (a) the nominal value of the shares (b) the amount of any premium payable on those shares; (c) the description of the consideration(d) the extent to which the nominal value of the shares and any premium are to be treated as paid up(i) by the consideration; (ii) in cash. I will not read any further. The point I am trying to make simply is that there is more than ample coverage in a provision if it were inserted in the Bill to cover this situation as has been done in the United Kingdom Act. As T said earlier I see no reason at all why in fact the Ministerial Councilor its advisers could not have examined this provision in the period they have had. It is not an unusual provision to be in the United r:ingdom Act. It is also far more competently set out, if I might say so, in the Swedish Act. In looking at the position generally it is an indictment again of the Ministerial Council and its advisers. Clause agreed to. Clauses 114 and llS-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Sittings suspended from 6 to 8 p.m. Clause 116 agreed to. Clause 117 (Power to make certain payments).

Title: PAIRS

I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard sections 23 to 27 of the United Kingdom Companies Act of 1980. Leave granted. The document read asfollows23 -(1) A public company shall not allot shares as fully or partly paid up (as to their nominal value or any premium payable on them) otherwise than in cash if the consideration for the allotment is or includes an undertaking which is to be or may be performed more than five years after the day of the allotment. (2) Where a public company allots shares in contravention of subsection (I) above, the allottee of the shares shall be liable to pay the company an amount equal to their nominal value, together with the whole of any premium, or, if the case so requires, such proportion of that amount as is treated as paid up by the undertaking and shall be liable to pay interest at the appropriate rate on the amount payable under the foregoing provision. (3) Where a contract for the allotment of shares does not contravene subsection (1) above, any variation of the contract which has the effect that the contract would have contravened that SUbsection if the terms of the contract as varied had been its original terms shall be void. the consideration or that part of (4) Subsection (3) above shall apply to the variation by a public company of the terms of a contract entered into before the company was re-registered as a public company. Any reference in this section to a contract for the allotment of shares includes a reference to an ancillary contract relating to payment in rcspect of those shares. 24 -(1) Subject to subsection (2) below, a public company shall not allot shares as fully or partly paid up (as to their nominal value or any premium payable on them) otherwise than in cash unless(a) the consideration for the allotment has been valued in accordance with the following provisions of this section; (b) a report with respect to its value has been made to the company by a person appointed by the company in accordance with those provisions during the six months immediately preceding the allotment of the shares; and (c) a copy of the report has been sent to the proposed allottee of the shares. (2) Subsection (1) above shall not apply to the allotment of shares by a company in connection with(a) an offer made by the company to all the holders of the shares in another company to acquire all or some of those shares or to all holders of a particular class of those shares to acquire all or some of the shares of that class; or (b) a proposed merger of that company with another company. (3) In determining for the purposes of subsection (2) above whether an offer is so made by a company (in this subsection referred to as the "offeror company"), shares held by or by a nominee of the offeror company in the other company or held in the other company by or by a nominee of a company which is the offeror company's holding company or its subsidiary or a company which is a subsidiary of its holding company shall be disregarded; and for those purposes there is a proposed merger of two companies when one of them proposes to acquire all the assets and liabilities of the other in exchange for the issue of shares in that one to shareholders of the other, with or without any cash payment to those shareholders. (4) The valuation and above shall be made by an independent person, that is to say, a person qualified at the time of the report to be appointed or continue to be auditor of the company, except that where it appears to him to be reasonable for the valuation of the consideration, or a valuation of part of the consideration, to be made, or to accept such a valuation made, by any person who(a) appears to him to have the requisite knowledge and experience to value the consideration or that part of the consideration; and (b) is not an officer or servant of the company or any other body corporate which is that company's subsidiary or holding company or a subsidiary of that company's holding company or a partner or employee of such an officer or servant; he may arrange for or accept such a valuation, together with a report which will enable him to make his own report under that subsection and provide a note in accordance with subsection (7) below. (5) The independent person's report under subsection (1) above shall slale (a) the nominal value of the shares to be wholly or partly paid for by the consideration in question; (b) the amount of any premium payable on those shares; (c) the description of the consideration and, as respects so much of the consideration as he himself has valued, a description of that part of the consideration, the method used to value it and the date of the valuation; (d) the extent to which the nominal value of the shares and any premium are to be treated as paid up(i) by the consideration; (ii) in cash. (6) Where any consideration is valued under this section by a person other than the independent person, the latter's report under subsection (1) shall state that fact and shall also(a) state the former's name and what knowledge and experience he has to carry out the valuation; and (b) describe so much of the consideration as was valued by that other person, state the date of valuation. (7) The report of the independent person made under subsection (1) above shall contain or be accompanied by a note by him(a) in the case of a valuation made by another person, that it appeared to the independent person reasonable to arrange for it to be so made or to accept a valuation so made; (b) whoever made the valuation, that the method ofvaluation was reasonable in all the circumstances; (c) that it appears to the independent person that there has been no material change in the value of the consideration in question since the valuation; and (d) that on the basis of the valuation the value of the consideration, together inal value of the shares or any premium payable on them is to be paid up, is not less than so much of the gregate of the nominal value and the whole of any such premium as is treated as paid up by the consideration and any such cash. (8) Subsection (9) below applies where a public company allots any share in contravention of subsection (1) above and either(a) the allottee has not received a report under this section; or (b) there has been some other contravention of this section and the allottee knew or ought to have known that it amounted to a contravention. report required by subsection (1) (9) Where this subsection applies, the allottee shall be liable to pay the company an amount equal to the nominal value of the shares, together with the whole of any premium or, if the case so requires, such proportion of that amount as is treated as paid up by the consideration, and shall be liable to pay interest at the appropriate rate on the amount payable under the foregoing provision. (10) Subsection (4) of section 20 above shall apply for the purposes of this section as it applies for the purposes of that.
