Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Clauses 116 and 117, when read together, clearly seek to limit a limited liability company to issuing shares at a discount of up to 10 per cent provided that the companies memoranda or articles do not prohibit the practice. That is referred to in clause 117 (1) (a). It parrots paragraph 302 of the explanatory memorandum with which the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) has kindly furnished the Parliament. That paragraph indicates that clause 117 applies to all payments, not just to commissions and brokerage which the explanatory memorandum states, in effect, that the provision deals with. Sub-clause 117 (2) states: . . . the allowance of a discount by a company shall be taken to be the making of a payment by the company. Consequently, the provisions of the following clause, clause 118, which are aimed at ensuring the creditors and shareholders are not prejudiced by the discount share issues, have no application to discounts of up to 10 per cent. Clause 117 ought to be amended so that it covers only commissions paid to underwriters and a brokerage paid to registered sharebrokers in connection with an issue of company shares. I would like some response from the ministerial advisers on that matter. I think the part of the Bill dealing with commissions was intended to make it clear that companies could legitimately pay underwriting and brokerage commissions incurred in issuing shares without infringing the prohibition of issuing shares at a discount. It is worded very broadly, and it is arguable that a company could legitimately issue shares to anyone under this clause at a discount of up to 10 per cent. I suggest it ought to be amended so that it authorises only underwriting commissions, salesmen's commissions and brokerage commissions incurred in the issue of company shares. I believe that clause is defective to that extent, and again I ask the Minister to raise the matter in the Ministerial Council. Clause agreed to. Clauses 118 to 124-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 125 (Rights of holders of classes of shares).

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Hawker) (8.5)-This clause relates to re-operation. The National Companies Bill, a private member's Bill introduced by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith ( Mr Lionel Bowen) in 1976, abolished the articles of memorandum distinction and simply adopted the concept of company rules. Clause 73(1) provides that the memorandum of a company may be altered to the extent and in a manner provided by the Act, but not otherwise. Clause 73 (2) provides: Subject to this section, sub-section 78 (3) and section 320, if a provision of the memorandum of a company could lawfully have been contained in the articles of the company, the company may, unless the memorandum prohibits the alterations of that provision, alter that provision by special resolution. Clause 73 (5) states: Nothing in sub-section (2) permits the alteration of a provision of the memorandum of a company that relates to rights to which only members included in a particular class of members are entitled. In other words, class rights clauses cannot be altered under this provision. The question I raise with the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) is whether clause 125 (2) permits the alteration of a class rights clause which is contained in the company's memorandum of association, where there is no existing variation procedure, prohibition or variation. Clause 125 (2) (a) applies where rights are attached to shares included in a class of shares. But nowhere in clause 125 is there any express reference to the rights clause itself, as distinct from the variation of the rights clause-that is important-being in the memorandum of association. Clause 125 (2) expressly allows the memorandum to be altered so as to include a variation of the rights clause. I can see the ministerial advisers are certainly following the problem. Clause 125 (2) does not expressly or by necessary implication state that class rights provisions in the memorandum of association may be altered by adhering to the stated procedure. It must therefore be considered doubtful that such a provision could be altered under clause 125 when clauses 72 and 73 are borne in mind. I suggest that that is where the conflict exists. Perhaps this doubt could be resolved. I ask the Minister to reconsider this and perhaps the Ministerial Council and the advisers could look at it and amend clause 125 (2) to read: 'Rights are attached to shares included in a class of shares whether in the memorandum of articles of association of the company or otherwise'. It seems clear from clause 125 (3) that rights clauses in the memorandum are included and intended to be altered. The consequential amendment to clause 126 is obvious. It would have to read: 'Rights are attached to shares in a company whether in a memorandum of articles of association or the company, or otherwise'. There would also have to be a consequential amendment to clause 127. I ask the Minister to look at that. I believe there are some anomalies and that at least that part of the legislation should be straightened up. MI' MOORE (Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (8.9)--1 will look at the points the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi) has raised. My interpretation of the situation is somewhat different. My advisers will look at the suggestions to ascertain what they mean. Clause agreed to. Clauses 126 to 128-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clauses 129 to 136-by leave-taken together.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (8.10)Part of the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill related to clauses 129 to 136. We asked for the reform of the provisions relating to companies financing dealings in their own shares, including the deletion of salaried directors from the definition of employees. Of course, the Labor Party approves of any scheme to assist employees to buy shares in the company they work for. However, we feel that often these schemes are really only perks for directors. The privileges do not usually get down to those on the shop fioor. In fact, in the United Kingdom the Labor Government's companies Bill of 1978 recognised the possibility of abuse and excluded salaried directors from the definition of employees. We certainly agree with that. We believe that the provision in clause 129 (I) (a) and (b) which exempts financial assistance in respect of any director holding salaried employment or an officer of the company from the provision of these clauses is unwarranted and should be removed. Clause 129 (4) states: . . . a company shall be taken to have given financial assistance in connection with an acquisition or proposed sition referred to in paragraph (1) (a) if, when the financial assistance was given to a person, the company was aware that the financial assistance would financially assist-I pose a question to the Minister in relation to clause 129 (4). How can a company be aware that financial assistance would t1nancially assist? It seems to be a pejorative question to begin with but in the absence of any deeming provision it must be wondered which of the company's officers or employees must be aware of the relevant facts for the company to be held to be aware of the same facts. It need only be said that in the state of the common law at present the criteria governing those persons who can bring this primary liability on a company are very ill-defined. We are asking for some assistance in that area. I hope that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) will heed those remarks and refine the language of clause 129. More particularly, we are concerned at the possibility of employees not getting the advantage that is obviously intended because, as I have pointed out, when these things are promulgated they normally do not go to those most in need. We also have some grave reservations about clause 130, which relates to the consequences of a company financing dealings in its own shares. We feel that some sad consequences could follow from that sort of practice. Notwithstanding commercial opinion to the contrary, some provisions are necessary to catch certain abusers. I give a couple of examples. For instance, person A may borrow money to take over company B and then strip the assets of company B to finance the loan he used to purchase the company in the first place. That is a perfectly good example of the consequences of companies financing dealings in their own shares. Another example is when the controllers of a company strip the assets of that company to feather their own shareholdings. We are very worried about that. The wording of clause 129 (4) (b) may not extend to the first mentioned abuse, that is, person A borrowing from company B to finance the purchase of the same company, because of the phrase 'of the subscription' which is included in the text. The Minister should look into these clauses and bring some of the difficulties before the Ministerial Council. If he does so there may be some improvements in the drafting of those clauses to eliminate possible abuses.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (8.15)-1 take notice of what has been said. This is a very technical area. Whilst the Government did not accept the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second acqui- reading of the Bill, I will look into the matters raised in it. I think the proposition of employee shares is a vital one in the administration of any company and every encouragement ought to be given to their issue. The difficulty lies not so much with the companies and the issue of the shares but with the taxation implications. Under the present Income Tax Assessment Act those shares afford a disadvantage to employees rather than a straight out advantage. The problem lies not so much within the Companies Act as within the Income Tax Assessment Act. As a general rule, whilst the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown) seemed to suggest that only directors or senior executives were the participants-Mr John Brown-No, not necessarily. The danger is there that they might well be.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: - I take the point. The most important thing to me is that the advantages ought to be open to all employees. Naturally, they will depend on the scale of responsibility. In my view, companies would be well advised to look at the issue of employees' shares in their own interests and in the interests of the shareholders. Secondly, I think that the redemption of shares is a very technical area. I noticed recently an article by the Australian Merchant Bankers Association which supported the proposition. In principle, I think there is a lot to recommend it. It is a practice used in the United States of America in redemption of certain shares under financial conditions of a company. There are circumstances in which it would be of advantage to a corporation. Whilst I do not think that is the general application, it may well be that the Ministerial Council should give consideration to its application with certain qualifications. Clauses agreed to. Clauses 137 to 228-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 229 (Duty and liability of officers) .

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Hawker) (8.18)-1 want some clarification of clause 229. I have discussed it with the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) who had the courtesy to allow me to discuss it with his ministerial advisers. We disagreed, but I would like to put the matter on the record for future reference. I raised the position of receivers appointed out of court under clauses 229 (5) and 535 (4) as distinct from receiver managers. Subject to clause 229 they cannot seek relief from the court under clause 535. I can anticipate the answer from the Minister that the word 'officer' in the definition clause as well in clause 535 (4) has a broader meaning than the definition under clause 5 (1). I do not accept that. However, I suggest to the Minister that he return to the drawing board and introduce an appropriate amendment which I will indicate later. Under clause 535, the court has the power to grant relief to certain persons in connection with civil proceedings brought against them for negligence, default, breach of trust or a breach of duty. Breaches of clause 229 would be within clause 535 to the extent that a company has a civil right to claim loss or damage sustained as a result of a breach of clause 229 (6). The persons who can seek relief under clause 535 are set out in clause 535 (4). They are (a) an officer of a corporation; (b) an auditor of a corporation; (c) an expert; or (d) a receiver, receiver and manager, liquidator or other person appointed or directed by the court to carry out any duty under this Act in relation to a corporation. The question which I pose is: Are previously appointed receivers entitled to seek relief under clause 535? Rather anomalously the answer would appear, in my view, to be no. The reference to 'officer' in clause 535 (4) (a) seems to be a reference to 'officer' as defined in clause 5 (1 )-that is, the definition clauserather than 'officer' as defined in clause 229. That this seems so is clear by the reference in clause 535 (4) (d) to court appointed receivers and receivers and managers. This provision would be unnecessary if 'officer' was intended to be covered by the definition in clause 229 because that definition clearly embraces court appointed receivers and receivers and managers, whereas the clause 5 (I) definition expressly excludes them. Clause 535 (4) should be amended so that it covers all persons, and in particular privately appointed receivers, who come within the clause 229 definition of 'officer'. I suggest to the Minister that we ought to amend that clause as follows: Clause 535 by adding to sub-clause (e) 'a receiver of the property or - ny part of the. pro-erty . of the co!'poration appointed under a power contained In an Instrument. That would overcome what is in fact, in my view, a clear oversight. I will now deal with the question of clause 237. I believe the clause should be amended. Again, the word 'officer' as defined in clause 237 (1) would apply only to those persons within the clause 5 (1) definition of 'officer'. Consequently, clause 237 (1) would not catch exemption or indemnification provisions relating to privately appointed receivers and court appointed receivers, receivers and managers an- liquidators. All of these classes of persons are subject to clause 229 which refers to duties in favour of the as company. It follows that 'officer' in clause 227 should have the same meaning as it has in clause 229. The same amendment should be inserted as in clause 229. I also suggest to the Minister that he take back to the Ministerial Council the suggestion that we add a new sub-clause to clause 229 which deals with the protection of shareholders. Such a provision is contained in the Swedish Act and it highlights in effect the total inadequacy of the current provision. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an extract of the Swedish Companies Act. I refer to chapter 9, section 3 of the 1975 Act. Leave granted. The section read asjollowsNobody may vote for more than one fifth of the total number of votes attributable to the shares represented at the meeting, unless otherwise provided in the articles of association. A shareholder may not take part in a vote personally or by proxy. with respect to 1. any legal action against himself, 2. his release from liability for damages or other obligations towards the company, or 3. any legal action against ility if, in respect to such matters, he has a material interest which may be contrary to that of the company. Paragraphs one and two shall be correspondingly applicable to a shareholder's representative.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: I thank the Committee. I hope that the Minister will take this provision on board. Mr Moore-I have so much now that I am almost going under.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Well, I think it might be helpful if we refer the matter to some of our good friends in the States. Section 3 of the Swedish Act, which has been incorporated in Hansard, states: Nobody may vote for more than one fifth of the total number of votes attributable to the shares represented at the meeting, unless otherwise provided in the articles of association. A shareholder may not take part in a vote personally or by proxy, with respect to I. any legal action against himself, 2. his release from liability gations towards the company, or 3. any legal action against others or their release from ility if, in respect to such matters, he has a material interest which may be contrary to that of the company. Paragraphs one and two shall be correspondingly applicable to a shareholder's representative. Section 7 of the Act states: A shareholder is entitled to have a matter dealt with at a general meeting of shareholders rectors has received a request the matter in the notice convening the meeting. No such provision is contained in the Companies Bill. There is a total absence of any such clause. It is a very vital provision and I would suggest that it is a matter that ought to be referred to the Ministerial Council for consideration.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (8.25)-I wish to make a few short remarks on clause 229 of the Companies Bill. We are asking for the provision of a higher required standard of competence, care and diligence for directors and officers of companies. I doubt that anybody would disagree with that as a sentiment. We feel that the provisions of the Bill set a fairly low standard in this area. The previous draft exposure had much more stringent requirements for diligence and care by directors. In fact, it imposed a stricter test and involved a certain amount of subjectivity. The draft stated that the care, diligence and skill required was to be not less than what a reasonably prudent person would exercise in relation to his own business or affairs in comparable circumstances. Unfortunately, the Confederation of Australian Industry, as well as other heavy lobby groups, has seen to it that the teeth have been taken out of the legislation which is now before us. others or their release from liabWe believe the standard of skill which is appropriate to directors and other officers should be made explicitly objective-that is, assessed according to the standards of a reasonable person, at least in relation to the directors on the board of a quoted company. The subjective criteria established in the present law let incompetent directors ofI far too lightly. T think that is a view that is universally accepted by many people, not only of the Opposition, but in the commercial area. The directors that we are talking about are only assessed according to the degree of confidence which persons of their background, experience and qualifications might be expected to have. Surely that leaves a great deal of value judgment to somebody who is adjudicating in this area. Whilst this approach is probably legitimate for directors of small backyard companies or perhaps the corner service station, it makes no sense to direcfor damages or other oblitors of large quoted companies, because these people certainly are quasi professionals, being liab- paid large sums to take care of shareholders' funds and also the money of creditors. To a great extent they are responsible for the tenure of employment of the workers. We feel that like other professionals, such as doctors or lawyers, their performance should be assessed on the objective standards. provided that the board of ditherefor early enough to include The companies Acts in Europe and particularly in the United Kingdom are more stringent in this area than is this Bill. We would hope that the Minister would make a more serious attempt to strengthen the supervision of directors in quoted companies as well as all other companies. Following on from the suggestions made to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) by the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi), perhaps the Minister might look at the provisions contained in the Swedish Bill. Perhaps thosc provisions might be able to be altered for or implemented in the Australian scene. We would hope so anyhow.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (8.28)-I wish to respond to the two propositions put forward by the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi). Undoubtedly he has done an enormous amount of work in this area and he is probably enjoying tonight's proceedings. It is arguable that the proposition which he put forward in relation to clause 535 of the Companies Bill is in itself any wider than the definition of 'officer' under clause 229. Mr Jacobi-It does not cover a receiver. That is the problem.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: No, but it is a marginal situation. The honourable member cannot claim the points that he has been claiming on the basis of that argument. I understand what he is talking about. I will agree to look at it. But I do not believe the force of his argument really offsets the two balances. In relation to the matters put forward by the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown), I can only say that the company directors are the owner's representatives. Those are the facts of life. The board of directors represents the owners. The managing director is the management. I can understand that some sensitivities exist when one looks at the Australian Labor Party in Queensland in relation to its broadcasting station. Some considerable difficulties and problems are being experienced in recognising who represents the owners of the ALP radio station. I can understand the particular interest in the subject. Nevertheless the competence, care and skill of those gentlemen is now being tested in the Supreme Court of Queensland. That will make remarkable reading. I am sure the honourable member had that matter in mind. The appointment of directors is of considerable significance. The directors represent the proprietors of the corporation. In my view people are sometimes appointed as directors because they are friends within friends rather than people with straight out management competence for appointment to directorships. I understand the points that have been brought forward. The members of boards should recognise that they represent proprietary interests. Clause agreed to. Clauses 230 to 246-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 247 (Circulation of members' resolutions, etc.).

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Hawker) (8.31)-1 raise again the matter of shareholders' rights. Those rights have been neglected by the provisions of the Bill. In relation to members' petitions, I suggest that clause 247 ought to be amended by replacing the words 'and (unless the company otherwise resolves) at the expense of those members' with the words 'at the expense of the company'. Under clause 247 (5) a company has the power to apply to the court to prevent the right specified in clause 247 (1) from being abused. This clause ought to be amended to extend the rights to individual members. They ought to be able to insist on the company forwarding details of any resolution of the members at the same time as the notice of meeting is sent to all members. This is abSent from the Bill. The expense ought to be borne by the company. It should also be possible for an individual shareholder to cause the company to circulate on his behalf a statement with respect to any business to be dealt with at the meeting. The circulation of these statements should arguably be at the shareholders' expense unless the company otherwise agrees. In any event, the expense could be minimised if the statement accompanied the notice of the meeting. This is yet another clear indication of the fact that little respect is shown to the shareholders in the provisions of the Bill. I raise one further matter which is not pertinent to the matter I have just mentioned. I have tried for a long time to get a provision in this respect included in the Bill. I refer to proxy shares. It has nothing to do with this section of the Bill, but I ask the Minister to think about this matter. I believe that proxy shares are an important part of shareholders' rights. A shareholder should have the right not only to appoint a proxy but also to instruct a proxy in certain specific and important areas, such as the appointment or dismissal of a director or an auditor. The shareholder is neglected in this respect in the provisions of this Bill.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (8.33)-A substantial number of corporations provide for proxies in the detached part of their annual reports and those proxies are not only about whom one wants to appoint but also about whether one wants to vote for or against a resolution or a person. I have seen this method adopted by a number of public corporations. Clause agreed to. Clauses 248 to 260-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 261 (Power of company to obtain information as to beneficial ownership of its shares).

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Hawker) (8.35)-1I have a certain amount of feeling about clause 261. The clause deals with the absence of nominee shares. Under sub-clause (5) a company has the right to disclose on request the beneficial owners of its shares. It is not obliged to do so. Sub-clause (4) states that once this ownership is disclosed by a company it is listed on a separate share register which sets out the beneficial owners. Sub-clause (5) states that separate parts of the register are open for inspection only by a member of the company or persons authorised so to do by the Corporate Affairs Commission. Sub-clause (9) gives the Corporate Affairs Commission power to exempt disclosure. I trust that I am reading accurately the provisions of the Bill on those four points. Mr John Brown-You are.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: I am grateful to the honourable member. A very interesting letter by Bertram Cox in the Adelaide Advertiser of August of last year puts this matter far more succinctly than I can. It states: The law imposes restrictions Australian company and also prescribes the maximum percentage they may acquire in any particular enterprise. Foreign investment in Australian companies is controlled, particularly in extractive invoked when more than a certain ownership of television stations trading by directors and others acceptable policies. Yet these controls can be nee companies, a trend that is growing in this country. Any person or company can buy as many shares as they desire, record them in XYZ Nominees Ltd and their ownership will remain as secret as a Swiss bank account. How wrong this is. It completely vitiates the intention of the legislation. The share registers of companies are open to inspection by the public, yet major shareholdings through this 'cloak and dagger' method remain concealed from view. If nominee companies are permitted to continue-and I remain unconvinced of their necessity or desirability·legislation should be introduced to require nominee companies-usually banks-to supply to companies a monthly list of the owners of shares held by them as nominees in those companies. This information would then become available, and rightly so, to the general public on a search of the companies' registers. Where is the justification for secrecy in what should be and otherwise is, a matter open to the public? Insofar as overseas companies Acts are concerned, whether they be in the European Economic Community, encompassing France, West Germany and the United Kingdom or in Canada and the United States, perhaps they are equally as defective as these Bills in relation to nominee shareholdings. I think this is regrettable and scandalous. I put a series of questions on the Notice Paper which highlight the utter deficiency of this piece of legislation. I asked the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) the following question: I. Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (8.42)-1 will take only a minute to reinforce the very strongly stated views of the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi). I think that anybody who was listening to him could only be impressed with his sincerity on this subject and his innate knowledge of the problems of this sort of shareholding. I repeat that we demand that the Companies Bill be amended to allow full disclosure to the public of the beneficial ownership of all shares in companies. Public accountability and the philosophy of disclosure demand that the information be open not only to the company but also to the public. Clause 261 (9) referring to the discretion of the National Companies and Securities Commission to exempt a person from the provision of the Bill is something which rather terrifies and horrifies us. I repeat our strong desire that the Bill be amended in this area and that the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities will see that full disclosure is available to everybody, so that anybody trading with a company will know with whom he is trading.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (8.43)--I also wish to compliment the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi) on his certain depth of knowledge of these matters. Clause 261 enables the company concerned to inquire of shareholders as to who the beneficial holders are. Having acquired that information it will then be registered in a special register which will be available to the National Companies and Securities Commission and to members of the company. I just give a brief outline as to why we have a nominee company. It is one of those things which mystique has also built up as a bogy. It is used for very valid commercial reasons, besides the matter of privacy. The commercial reasons are that, in a sense as a broker, one almost invariably runs one's own nominee company, because there are an enormous number of occasions when one has to accumulate shares or register shares to protect oneself against dividends or rights in an issue and that could not be done in one's name. Under the requirements of the Stock Exchange this has to be done through a nominee company. Exactly the same provision applies. therefore, to the banking nominee companies. These companies are very heavily used in certain personal cases and certainly in the cases of overseas investments in Australia. This is done through banking corporations, through nominee companies for the very precise reasons that one has to clear one's currency. Therefore, one is apt to use and register shares that are bought in London or New York and nominate those through a nominee company while one is clearing currency. The banks will not release the script until a person pays, or in the reverse, where a' person happens to be selling he registers it with the bank nominee company and declares those shares to the purchasers in New York, London or wherever on receipt of money. It is very obvious that nominee companies are heavily used in those situations for registration of overseas payments. Those are two valid reasons that brokers use them. Under the takeover code it is necessary, once a level of 20 per cent is reached under the new threshold agreement which will be applicable as a legislative base, I hope from 1 July, to declare one's hand. That in itself is a threshold means. I am aware, as well as anybody, that nominee companies have been used for a number of warehousing and other techniques. I am well aware of that. I do not wish to let the other side of the coin be shown. These companies are a very useful commercial device. 1 would support their use. Clause agreed to. Clause 262 agreed to. Clause 263 agreed to. Clauses 264 to 266-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clauses 267 to 276-by leave-taken together.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (8.47)We are now dealing with Division 2, accounts. I thought that the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi) was going to rise to speak to a previous clause which we did not debate. One point that T would like to make, Mr Deputy Chairman, if I have your indulgence-l think the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs would probably agree with me-is that we are insisting that companies should have more frequent accounts, at least for quoted companies. The reason that we particularly want to question the Companies Bill in that area is that there is a perfectly good example in the Associated Securities Ltd collapse a couple of years ago where people were still devoting their savings to a body which was at risk. If accounts had been published more frequently then perhaps these people may not have done just that because the previous years' accounts were no guide to the investors in that area. I am glad that I have had your indulgence, Mr Deputy Chairman, to make that remark. I get back to the area of accounts we are debating. In the exposure draft of the Companies Bill certain provisions were inserted as Part 6aa in relation to companies acting as trustees of trading trusts. In essence these provisions required the company to indicate on all its business documents that it was carrying on business as a trustee and to name the trust. They required the directors in their report, forming part of the annual accounts, to specify the business or businesses that were carried on by the company as trustees of a trading trust and to state whether the assets of the trust were sufficient to discharge the liabilities of the company as trustee. The Opposition welcomed those proposed provisions as being, firstly, an important protection to persons dealing with companies acting as trustees of trading trusts, alerting them that the company was not trading in its own right, and secondly, we found that it was a disincentive to the use of trading trusts as a vehicle for tax avoidance by requiring the trustee pacity of the company to be publicly disclosed. Perhaps-I might say this cynically-predictably these proposals brought a storm of protest from the corporate sector. Regrettably the Government succumbed and removed these provisions from the Bill in its second draft. We find that rather regrettable. We urge that legislation be prepared forthwith incorporating as a minimum the provisions of the original Part 6aa of the exposure draft. We bring this to the Minister's attention most forcefully. We find one of the real weaknesses of this Bill to be that those provisions that were so much of a reform nature in the exposure draft have been deleted from the Bill that we are now debating. I hope that will be another area in which the Minister might be able to use his good offices and no doubt his forceful arguments to prevail upon the Ministers of the Ministerial Council to see that that original draft be incorporated as an amendment in this legislation.

Speaker: Mr MOUNTFORD
Title: PAIRS
text: Banks) (8.51)-1 reinforce the comments made by the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown) in regard to this clause which deals with accounts and auditing. The Opposition has moved that the Bill be amended. I know that it cannot be amended at this stage because of problems with the States, but I think this is something that should be dealt with fairly quickly once the Act is proclaimed. We feel that the Bill is inadequate. I have three specific points to outline. Firstly, I know that in particular the existing legislation in New South Wales requires the principal accounting officers of the companies to state whether, to the best of their knowledge and belief, the accounts give a true and fair view of matters. That requirement does not appear anywhere in this Bill. Mr John Brown-It has been deleted.

Speaker: Mr MOUNTFORD
Title: PAIRS
text: It has been deleted. The requirements in the Bill for the keeping of accounts and the submitting of those accounts to a corporation or the Corporate Affairs Commission is pointless really if somebody does not take responsibility for them. This does not happen in this legislation. I feel that that is a major omission. Clause 270 (7) which deals with directors' reports does not require such reports to state the emoluments of directors to be included in the aggregate amount of emoluments shown in the accounts or the fixed salary of a director who is a full time employee. The latter is covered by an exemption which also is not contained in the existing legislation. I feel that it is a matter that should be ca- covered and I think the Minister should take that on board. 1 would just like to mention the matLer which the honourable member for ParramatLa raised regarding more frequent accounts being submitted rather than yearly accounts. I have mentioned that nobody takes responsibility for submitting more frequent accounts. Even if somebody took responsibility for the matter, we consider that the accounts should be submitted more frequently than once a year so that a trend is available not only to creditors but also to those people who are prepared to invest in such companies. As I mentioned earlier in the debate, this should apply particularly to companies of a high risk character. I think that the amendments outlined by the Opposition are sane amendments and that they should be proceeded with by the Government.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (8.54)-1 cannot accept the Opposition's amendments, for a couple of reasons which r shall outline. The honourable member for Banks ( Mr Mountford) should know that accounts of all public companies are submitted half-yearly. That is a requirement of listing on the stock exchange and it has been so for some considerable time. If one is in a risk area-the term the honourable member used, and I presume that relates to mining accounts are required to be produced on a quarterly basis. The companies come forward with quarterly production figures. On top of that, accounts are put out and signed by the executives of the company and also by one of the directors. The auditor is required to certify as to the accuracy of those accounts; so there is no point in saying that the accounts go out without verification or without the responsibility of the company. That is just not true. Mr Jacohi-You have to take into account the standard of the information, too.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: As the honourable member for Hawker said, and as I said last night, the standard of information in accounts varies enormously. By chance, the accounts I had last night showed an enormous amount of information. Generally speaking, those accounts which show too much information are not appreciated and are not read. The accounts that show too little would cause one to glance at them briefly because of their inadequacy. Directors' pay and emoluments are shown in the accounts; they are not shown as gross amounts. The accounts will signify the amount paid to executive and non-executive directors. The accounts do not itemise them; so one has to do a calculation to find out roughly what the directors would have got. But the figures are there if anyone wishes to look for them. Clauses agreed to. Clauses 277 and 278-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 279 (Exempt proprietary company need not appoint auditor in certain circumstances) .

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Hawker) (8.56)-This clause deals with the exempt liability of proprietary companies dealing with auditors. My view is that this clause should be deleted from the Bill. I also believe that clause 277 (2) and (6) should be amended by inserting the word 'unlimited' between 'and' and 'exempt proprietary company'. Regarding clause 370, the remedy in cases of oppression or injustice should be to replace the provision modelled on section 75 of the United Kingdom Companies Act 1980. That section covers the following areas: Isolated acts of oppression; proposed or anticipated oppression; and single acts-past, actual or anticipated-acts of oppression. To some extent the Minister has covered multiple acts, but the question of anticipated acts has not been covered. Mr Moore-What clause are you on?

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Clause 320. Mr John Brown-We are only on clause 279.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: This clause deals with the same problem. I want to canvas the two issues now so I do not need to come back to the matter. I ask leave of the Minister to incorporate in Hansard section 75 of the United Kingdom Act which refers to proposed new sections 320 and 279. Leave granted. The document read asfollows75.(1) Any member of a company may apply to the court by petition for an order under this section on the ground that the affairs of the company are being or have been conducted in a manner which is unfairly prejudicial to the interests of some part of the self) or that any actual or proposed act or omission of the company (including an act or omission on its behalf) is or would be so prejudicial. (2) If in the case of any company(a) the Secretary of State has received a report under section 168 of the 1948 Act (inspectors' reports) or exercised his powers under Part III of the 1967 Act or section 36 (2) to (6) of the Insurance Companies Act 1974 (inspection of company's books and papers); and (b) it appears to him that the affairs of the company are being or have been conducted in a manner which is unfairly prejudicial to the interests of some part of the members or that any actual or proposed act or omission of the company (including an act or omission on its behalf) is or would be so prejudicial, he may himself (in addition to or instead of presenting a petition for the winding-up of the company under section 35 (l) of the 1967 Act) apply to the court by petition for an order under his section. (3) lfthe court is satisfwd that a petition under this section is well founded it may make such order as it thinks fit for givingreliefin respect of the matters complained of. (4) Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (3) above, an order under this section may(a) regulate the conduct of the company's affairs in the future; (b) require the company to refrain from doing or continuing an act complained of by the petitioner or to do an act which the petitioner has complained it has omitted to do; (c) authorise civil proceedings to be brought in the name and on behalf of the company by such person or persons and on such terms as the court may direct; (d) provide for the purchase of the shares of any members of the company by other members or by the company itself and, in the case of a purchase by the company itself, the reduction of the company's capital accordingly. (5) Where an order under this section requires the company not to make any, or any specified, alteration in the memorandum or articles then, notwithstanding anything in the Companies Acts, the company shall not have power without the leave of the court to make any such alteration in breach of that requirement. (6) Any alteration in the memorandum or articles of the company made by virtue of an order under this section shall be of the same effect as if duly made by resolution of the company and the provisions of the Companies Act shall apply to the memorandum or articles as so altered accordingly. (7) An office copy of any order under this section altering, or giving leave to alter, a company's memorandum or articles shall, within 14 days from the making of the order or such longer period as the court may allow, be delivered by the company to the registrar of companies for registration; and if a company makes default in complying with this subsection, the company and every officer of the company who is in default shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding one-fifth of the statutory maximum or, on conviction after continued contravention, a default fine not exceeding one-fiftieth of the statutory maximum for every day until that copy is delivered. (8) In relation to a petition under this section, section 365 of the 1948 Act (general rules for winding up) shall apply as it applies in relation to a winding-up petition. members (including at least him(9) This section shall apply to a person who is not a member of a company but to whom shares in the company have been transferred or transmitted by operation of law as it applies to a member of the company, and references to a member or members shall be construed accordingly. (1) In subsections (2) to (9) above "company" means any body corporate which is liable Act. (11) Section 210 of the 1967 Act (which are superseded by this section) shall cease to have effect except in relation to proceedings on a petition presented before the appointed day. Clause agreed to. Clauses 280 to 319-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 320 (Remedy in cases of oppression or injustice) .

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (8.58)We are now discussing Part IX of the Bill which deals with the conduct of affairs of a company in an oppressive or unjust manner. In the best of all worlds, I guest that that type of behaviour might not happen, but humans .being humans and companies being companies, it does happen; so this is a very important Part. In our amendment we ask: (b) adequate remedies for oppressive conduct, including extension of the concept of oppression to single and anticipated acts unfairly prejudicial of further means such as a 'shareholders' Tribunal' to protect the interests of minority shareholders, Clause 320 constitutes a limited advance on the present section 186 relating to the oppression of shareholders. Clause 320 (1) (a) and clause 320 (2) are new clauses entitling a member of a company to apply for the winding up of the company if he believes: that directors have acted in their own interests and not in the interests of the members as a whole or in any other manner whatsoever that is unfair or unjust to one or more of the members We cannot altogether disagree with that. This innovation, however, merely restates in a different part of the Bill the right of a member which is already contained in clause 364 (1) (f). The remedy of oppression has been seriously restricted in its application by the courts. The Opposition believes that the concept of oppression should be replaced by the concept of unfair prejudice which is referred to in the section of the English Bill to which the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi) referred. That section was recommended by the Jenkins Committee in the United Kingdom in 1962. Only by lowering the threshold will this become a meaningful remedy for oppressed minorities. In addition the tendency of the courts to require a course of conduct before finding oppression should be replaced by a provision that single acts of prejudice are sufficient to attract the remedy. The Opposition believes further that the concept of a shareholders' tribunal warrants closer scrutiny as a further means to shareholder protection. It is to be lamented that, when so much attention in the Companies to be wound up under th\l 1948 (Acquisition of Shares) Bill has been devoted to the protection of shareholders, this urgent reform 1948 Act and section 35(2) of the has been overlooked in the Companies Bill. I recommend that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) have a look at that section which the honourable member for Hawker has incorporated in Hansard. I think it is a much more advanced concept with regard to oppression of shareholders than is contained within this Bill. I hope that that would be one other area to which some urgent reform could be made. Perhaps the Minister could start the ball rolling in that area on the Ministerial Council. Clause agreed to. Clauses 321 to 323-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 324 (Liability of receiver).

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Hawker) (9.3)-1 will not delay the Committee on this clause. Clause 324, as I understand it, establishes no duty of care for the receiver. I have the New Zealand Companies to a shareholder; and provision Amendment Act. I seek leave of the Committee to have part of new section 345B of the Act incorporated in Hansard. Leave granted. The section read as followsIt provides that a receiver or manager of the property of a company who sells any of that property shall exercise all reasonable care to obtain the best price reasonably obtainable as at the time of sale. This duty is expressed to be one that is owed by the receiver to the company; and it is not to be a defence to any action or proceeding brought by the company against the receiver or manager in respect of a breach of that duty that the receiver or manager was acting as the agent of the company, or under a power of attorney given by the company. Neither is the receiver or manager entitled to be indemnified or compensated by the company for any liability he may incur as a result of the breach of his duty.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: I suggest to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mf Moore) that that section be included in the Bill which we are presently debating. I request that this suggestion go to the Ministerial Council for consideration. Clause agreed to. Clauses 325 to 357-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clauses 358 to 474-by leave-taken together.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Parramatta) (9.5)These clauses of the Bill are headed 'Part XUWinding Up'. I guess that is relevant as we are getting to the winding up stage of this epic saga with the Companies Bill. Our complaint about Part XII, to a great extent, relates to its huge extent because the provisions relating to winding up cover some 117 clauses of the Bill. Part XII extends from clause 358 to clause 474. A quick perusal of the structure of the clauses in the index to the Bill shows the complex nature of the provisions relating to the different forms of winding up. Unfortunately, in Australia, there has never been a full examination of the procedures and requirements relating to corporate insolvency, although the legislative provisions relating to individual bankruptcies receive close scrutiny. I suggest that, in view of the enormous number of bankruptcies that are occurring around Australia and that have occurred since this Government came to office, it is high time that a first class look was given to the whole area of insolvency. The Australian Law Reform Commission has requested a reference from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on the whole question of insolvency. To date, the Government has indicated that it does not intend giving such a reference to the Commission. We feel that the Law Reform Commission has done excellent work in such areas and that, since it has requested such a brief from the Government, it is almost sinful that the Government has not made an attempt to give it that brief. Simplification of the winding up provisions and the consideration of the vastly divergent interests of secured and unsecured creditors are two important reasons to justify such a reference. We feel very strongly on this point that the part of the Bill that requires 117 clauses to examine the whole subject of winding up of companies is mute testimony to the fact that the whole process is far too involved. We ask that the Minister urgently heed the request by the Law Reform Commission and give it a brief to look at this whole area of winding up.

Speaker: Mrs CHILD
Title: PAIRS
text: Henty) (9.7)-1 draw the attention of the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) to clause 441 which relates to priority payments. I understand that these payments are also mentioned in the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill. Sub-clause (e) states that the fifth payment in priority to all other unsecured debts is the wages in respect of services rendered to the company by employees before the relevant date, but not exceeding $2,000 in respect of anyone of the employees. We were disappointed to find that the Government did not accept the recommendation of the Senate Select Committee that the Crown priority would be abrogated and that the secured debts would come first and then the employees would come after. My colleague, the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown) will move an amendment to the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill. I point out that just as the investor invests money and so has security, so does the worker invest his labour and should be considered high in priority above all other debtors including the Commonwealth. We are aware that the States have not agreed to waive their claim. But I am sure that, if the Minister were to get together with the States, he could work something out that would give security to the worker who has invested his or her lahour.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Hawker) (9.9)-Clause 360 deals with the liabilities of contributors of present or past members. In dealing with corporate malfeasance I am reminded of that old dictum myoid father used to tell me. He said: 'As you go through life, lad, you will find plenty Sheriffs of Nottingham and very few Robin Hoods. To the former they give knighthoods and the latter they hang'. I note that the Minister agrees with that. Section 391 of the South Australian Companies Act provides that any transfer of shares made within a period of two years before the commencement of the winding up of the company to any person known by the transferor to be unable to pay the liability on those shares shall not relieve the transferor of that liability. It was considered that section 391 was sound in principle and should be retained in future legislation. That provision was subsequently incorporated in the South Australian Act. The Minister may recall the headline 'Garretty group creditors meet again today'. This head line referred to one of the most disgraceful episodes in Australian corporate history, and there have been enough of them. This episode concerned the Garretty group of companies and in particular the mutual trust Dividend Fund Inc. In this case not only did a group of mainly small investors lose the value of their shares but also they were personally liable for a $125,000 deficiency in the company. Mr Barry Jones-Unlike the Garrettys.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Unlike the Garrettys. Much of the fund's money was lent to other companies in the group of Garretty companies. In most Western countries this would not have been allowed. It could not happen under the South Australian Act. However, Dividend Fund was inhibited only by its articles of association, which were no inhibition whatsoever. It is essential that a provision such as section 391 of the South Australian Companies Act dealing with transfers to avoid liability be inserted into the national Act. There ought to be proper regulation of mutual funds. It is an indictment of the Government that there is an absence of such a provision in this legislation. There is no excuse for this. To add insult to injury, the Victorian Government was obliged to bailout a number of elderly people each to the tune of $4,500. These pensioners had put their life savings into this shonky group. I regret to say it, but it is true, that under this Government equality before the law means the right to rich men to sleep under bridges. I sincerely ask the Minister to take section 391 of the South Australian Act to the Ministerial Council as a means of ensuring that no more shonky deals like the Garretty situation are allowed to take place. Unless this provision is put in the federal legislation this situation will occur again. I will read to the Committee section 391 of the South Australian Act, which is concerned with transfer to avoid liability. Sub-section (1) is not pertinent to this legislation, but I will read it nonetheless. It states: Any transfer of a share in purpose of avoiding or evading liability with regard to such share, shall not relieve the transferor of any such liability. I will now read sub-section (2), which is relevant to the legislation before the Committee. Subsection (2) states: No transfer of a share in any company made for the purpose of avoiding or evading liability shall relieve the transferor of any such liability, if the transfer is made to any person for a nominal consideration, or for no consideration, or for valuable consideration expressed, but not paid to the transferor, or for a consideration paid to the transferee, or with a trust or reservation the benefit of the transferor, or to a person know to the transferor to be unable to pay the liability on such share, unless such transfer has been made and registered two years before the company is wound up. It is appalling that there is a complete absence of such a provision from this Bill. This is an indictment of the Federal Government's advisers. Unless that loophole is plugged the same position will be exploited ad infinitum. I ask the Minister to insert in the national Companies Bill the provision in the South Australian Companies Act.

Speaker: Mr MOUNTFORD
Title: PAIRS
text: Banks) (9.15)-1 would like to refer briefly to clauses 440 and 441. Clause 440 provides that all debts will rank equally unless otherwise provided in the legislation. This obviously refers to debenture holders and other secured creditors, who would obviously rank above the creditors mentioned in clause 441. So far as paragraphs (e), (f) and (g) of clause 441 are concerned, I think that wages, compensation for injuries to employees, long service leave and so forth should rank above even secured creditors. In the normal course of events, if a company is going along quite satisfactorily the wages, salaries, long service leave entitlements and so forth are payable when they fall due, either weekly or when a person takes leave. A company which is going bad does not always keep the payment of wages to employees up to date. It puts off the payment of wages because it thinks that they are probably one of the last things that need to be paid. In many instances it is a subsidiary company which is being wound up and the holding company will escape scot free. It wants to maintain some credibility with its largest creditors who are trading with the holding company. Of course, the people it can get rid of are the employees and the small creditors. Therefore I hope the Minister will be able to convince his colleagues in the other States that all of the wages and emoluments of employees should rank above even secured creditors in clause 440 and should not be relegated to the fifth, sixth and seventh positions in clause 441.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (9.18)-Clauses 358 to any company to an infant for the 474 are significant clauses, relating to the provisions for winding up. I think everybody has seen instances of this in recent times. Some companies have been wound up in a very spectacular fashion but most do not attract such attention. I think it is probably worthwhile at this point to make some reference to the winding up of a significant company. Opposition members seem to think that with regard to such share there is some conspiratorial atmosphere surrounding subsidiary companies. They are not designed by most corporations to be anything but an ordinary trading corporation entity. They generexpressed, or implied, for ally have a position in corporate strategy and part of that strategy is not to defraud. Mr Barry Jones-Remember what Adam Smith said.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: I am aware of that. I am also aware of what some other people say about the priorities and credibility of people in corporate life. They are not necessarily correct, just as Adam Smith's observations on economics were not necessarily correct. Therefore, I will get back to the question of liquidation of receiverships because they are important. Rather than start from the position that the honourable member for Henty ( Mrs Child) did, I would point to some of the facts which I think are relevant. It concerns me that these days, when a receivership gets under way and moves along to the inevitable liquidation, in the initial stages an evaluation of assets is made. On the basis of this valuation the receivers accounts are paid-they are substantial-so that at the end of the road the return to shareholders, secured creditors and other receivers under the plan sometimes are a good deal more than they were in the first case. This brings about the position where debentures or unsecured notes are sold on the market at substantial discounts to their real worth because the assessment in the first place is made, in no small way, by the receiver the liquidator on a valuation which he puts in newspapers and which everyone takes for definition granted. When the receiver gets to a position that is sometimes considerably more than was first out. The Patrick Partners corporation liquidation is one such example. Every honourable member seems to remember that case. Because of that I think we all ought to look at provisions to ensure, in the first place, that the write-down on not as significant or as excessive as it would be under real market forces which makes the receiver look a particularly smart performer, and also that people do not act because they are not fully informed. I think the honourable member for Henty used the words 'investors are secured'. Shareholders are not secured, but rank at the bottom of the They come after unsecured creditors who are relating right down at the bottom. The only secure invesprofits tors are those who have a registered mortgage against assets. Those distinctions should be known. The other point is that mutual funds have had a fairly disastrous history. I put that down no small way to the thing called the management area. company which is implanted into a lot of the mutual funds developed in Australia in the 1960s and the 19708. In future those funds will have to be looked at in terms of what is allowable for the management company within the structure. have a particular desire to see Australians invest, in a direct sense, in Australia. text: Hawker) (9.26)-1 will not of a delay the House but I wish to say something on the matter of no dividends except out of profits. I suggest that we replace this provision with sections 39 and 40 of the United Kingdom Companies Act. I will read from these sections so that they will be recorded in Hansard. That is precisely the argument and is the sort of argument which the Minister used when talking on the last provision of the Bill. It is ironic, as I said last night, that the United Kingdom has adopted a more stringent definition than we have done. I will briefly read from the two United Kingdom sections. Section 39 states: (l) A company shall not make a distribution except out of profits availablefor the purpose . . . (2) For the purpose of this part . . . a company's profit available for distribution, profits, so far as not previously utilised by distribution or capisaying talisation, less its accumulative or realised losses, so previously written off in a reduction or re-organisation capital duly made. Section 40 states: A public company may only make a distribution at any time: (a) if at that time the amount of its net assets is not less than the aggregate of the companies called up share capital and its undistributable reserves; and (b) if, and to the extent that, the distribution does not reduce the amount of those assets to less than that aggregate. I suggest that until we include those sorts of provisions in the Bill we will not get the coverage that we want.

Very few companies . these days, if they apply current cost accounting directly to their operations, would come out with a profit because of the inflationary effect and because of the provision which comes out of that. In certain areas they would but without any doubt that would not be the case in the general manufacturing area. On top of that, as an accounting The principle one has to have some realisation of what received profit is when there are substantial unrealised prepared losses in the accounts. This applies particularly certain companies which are carrying forward I depreciated assets when those companies decide crucial, for one reason or another not to take their loss that particular year but to carry it forward. That has a significant impact on profit within the declared year. That can be an adjustment of the stock figure in the normal trading company or it can relate to assets which have been disposed of or which have become redundant for which the loss has not been taken into account. In terms of determining profit one should look also at the taxation aspects. A corporation or a proprietary company can apply to pay a dividend which represents more than gross earnings for the year. That meets the requirements of the 60 per cent payout and gives substantial tax credits into the future. Once again profits, under those circumstances, are in a different situation. When we talk of profit, we really have a moving feast and . . . one has to understand the criteria on which we should rely. I can appreciate the honourable member's need for definition of profit; all I am are its accumulated realised is that in arriving at that position first of all far as not we must determine our accounting standard. I am of referring to historical, current cost accounting. text: Hawker) (9.33)-1 want to raise I with the Minister the question of Schedule 9 a which now, in effect, goes into the legislation by way of regulation to complete the Bill. The Ministo ter and I have had a lengthy exchange on the need an accounting standards review board. In his acrecent answer to my question on notice No. 418, . . decided to refer to the National Companies and Securities Commission for consideration and report: (a) the question of the establishment of the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee; and (b) the question of the cstablishment of the Accounting Standards Review Board and the South Australian 'Report on the Committee of Inquiry into the Registration and Conduct of Accountants'. Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities has and is still considering a preliminary paper that was for it by the National Companies and Securities in Commission of the Accounting Standards Review Board. agree with the Minister's preceding remarks; it is for a variety of reasons, to get an accountin ing standards review committee. As the Minister knows, the current Schedule 9, which is going into the legislation by way of regulations-with which we on this side of the House certainly agree- - is much less effective than the charter set down by the respective accounting bodies. We both agree on that. I want to raise two issues relating to Schedule 9, particularly in regard to clause 2L. I suggest that the Schedule is inadequate in a number of important aspects. I trust that my repeated requests for an accounting standards review board finally will be heeded by the Ministerial Council. Perhaps the Minister might give me some indication at this stage of just how far the Ministerial Council has got in regard to that. In my view, two sub-clauses should be added to clause 2L of Schedule 9. There are a couple of reasons for that. Firstly, turnover sales ought to be disclosed. They are not at the moment. Secondly, total wage and salary costs ought to be disclosed. There is no provision in Schedule 9 for that at the moment. Why is that? One cannot possibly calculate the efficiency of a firm without sales figures. The legislation is defective in that regard. It does not give shareholders the right to make a balanced evaluation for analysis of a company's liquidity. A second point on the matter of wages is that disclosure involves a socially significant payment to the community, to both shareholders and to the public. Obviously it is important for a number of other reasons. It is quite unfortunate that this provision has never appeared in Schedule 9. The other important factor is that employers can gauge distribution to employees, governments and shareholders. This provision is equally important-I can understand the corporate sector not wanting this-in order to determine the wages component in the price structure. I hope the Ministerial Council, whatever it does and whatever guidelines and criteria it fixes, ranks those two matters as important. It is appalling that such information is not disclosed-not made public-to enable proper evaluation. I go back to what the Minister said before. I have a different point of view. The situation to which I refer occurs in insurance companies in particular. Britain has found it to be much needed and long overdue to have more adequate information in balance sheets, whether they are quarterly, half-yearly or annual balance sheets. We tend to overlook the fact that 15 per cent of company shareholders cannot understand a balance sheet. Of those remaining-the real watchdogs-only 4 per cent or 5 per cent, excluding directors, can understand balance sheets. The failure to provide for appropriate disclosures on balance sheets is one of the real difficulties in effecting the early detection ofliquidity problems. In regard to proper accountancy procedures, I want to raise with the Minister a matter that I consider to be critically important. It is one that I hope he takes to the Ministerial Council. In my view it should rank extremely highly amongst the criteria fixed ultimately by the review board. It is an issue that ought to be given priority. I ask the Minister to take a brief and refer it to the National Companies and Securities Commission for urgent consideration. Perhaps the Minister will understand and grasp that concept more than most others. I am dealing now with winding up, liquidation, and things such as that. The brief is this: The Companies Act must give some guidance in determining the criteria which should be used for changing from going concern values to liquidation values. Mr Moore-Yes, I was talking about that.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: PAIRS
text: Exactly. I think it is an appalling defect. I will undertake to put an appropriate question on the Notice Paper, perhaps tomorrow. If we consider the number of companies that have gone into liquidation, this sort of information, this sort of criteria, is critically important.

text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (9.41)- The latter point raised by the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi) was the point to which I was referring when I responded previously. I have very grave reservations about the practice of making valuations, announcing valuations, on which people hold securities. They can then sell them and come out subsequently, some years later, with a far better result. Certainly the amounts returned by the receiver are substantial. On the question of accounting procedures and accounting reviews, there is no doubt at all that standards vary enormously. However, I do not accept that the way to do something in this life is to adopt the view: When in doubt, regulate. There is a great old bureaucratic practice which says: 'We do not know anything about it. We will regulate it'. I have seen governments in Queensland and in other places do this. The most appropriate course would be for the National Securities Commission to determine the minimum acceptable to it--not the maximum but the minimum. From that base, discussions could be held with the Institute of Chartered Accountants or the Society of Accountants in which they could recognise what should become the minimum acceptable. By doing that we could save ourselves yet another government body, board or regulatory authority. At the same time, it is hoped that we would see accountants reach those standards. If they do not reach those standards, we will have to consider the opposite situation. I hope that common sense, commercial practice and a sense of professionalism will be such as to carry through these things. Remainder of Bill agreed to. CROWN DEBTS (PRIORITY) BILL 1981 Second Reading Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by MrMoore: That the Bill be now read a second time. Third Reading Mr JOHN BROWN (Parramatta) (9.46)-I move: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not opposing the Bill, the House: Second Reading (1) expresses its concern that Crown Priorities in relation to tax instalment deductions and witholding tax on dividends and interest remitted overseas, and the priority of the Crown in right of the States, have been preserved, and (2) calls upon the Government to(a) abolish all remaining Crown Priorities in right of the Commonwealth and to seek the abolition of all remaining Crown Priorities in the State sphere, and Third Reading (b) ensure that all wages and compensation payments to employees are given priority over all creditors'. In June 1978 the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs tabled in the Senate its report entitled 'Priority of Crown Debts'. The report was in response to a reference to the Standing Committee from the Senate on 21 April 1977 to review the right of priority of the Second Reading Crown over other creditors in matters of bankruptcy, corporate liquidations, and other cases of impecunious persons or corporations. In that report the Senate Standing Committee recommended the complete abrogation of all Crown priorities in insolvency administration. The Federal Government-this Government-went some way along the line. The then Minister for Business Third Reading and Consumer Affairs, the present Minister for Education ( Mr Fife), in a statement to the House of Representatives on 13 September 1979 said that the Government had examined the report and, whilst it was fully in agreement with the main thrust of the Committee's argument, it was not willing to abrogate its total rights to Crown priority. Second Reading The Government therefore went to the States with the view that the Crown should retain priority in the areas of tax instalment deductions, withholding tax on undistributed dividends, and interest remitted overseas. When it came time for the Ministerial Council to look at this proposition, the States were unwilling to forgo their rights. Because the Commonwealth was not prepared to Third Reading forgo all its rights, the States were likewise inclined. We now have the situation mentioned by the honourable member for Henty ( Mrs Child) and the honourable member for Banks ( Mr Mountford) in the debate on clause 441 of the Companies Bill, under which employees' rights come way down the line. The Opposition finds this an unacceptable and most reprehensible state of affairs. Firstly, in the case of a failed company, secured creditors get their slice. They are followed by the Commonwealth, then the State, and finally, way down the line, in paragraphs (e), (f) and (g), the employees have an opportunity to get something from what is left of the wreck. We cannot accept that as being a moral state of affairs. As the honourable member for Henty pointed out, and it has been pointed out in this debate by other speakers, the people who work for companies in fact are investing their labour in the fortunes of that company with just as much sincerity as a shareholder is investing his money. However, the particular characteristic of an employee's efforts is that in almost every case the only chance an employee of a company has of getting anything back is what he gains in wages from that company. The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) suggested some while back that shareholders come even further down the line than employees. Mr Moore-They do.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: Perhaps that might be a case of regret also. It may well be that a case is made out for them to have priority over the Crown. I think that the pertinent point to be remembered here is that most people who are investing in companies, particularly large public companies, do not have all their eggs in one basket. It is a very rare investor who puts all his money into one company. So it is possible that, if a company fails and an investor loses his or her investment in that company, he or she does have some other form of living; but with an employee that is not the case. We are not prepared to accept that salary earners, when accepting their share of what is left, are placed right at the bottom of the priority list. I put it very firmly to the Minister that the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill and section 441 of the Companies Bill should be looked at to see that our view, which was the view of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, is accepted and that employees rights are put right at the top of the list of priorities. The Commonwealth can hardly say that it has no other way of obtaining revenue. With all the avenues which are open to government, should it think that it is entitled to have a share above the wages which are due to employees in a failed company or of compensation payments due to employees? In fact, due to their downgraded position right at the bottom of the priorities list, the total possible payment to anyone employee under these circumstances is $2,000. Mr Deputy Speaker, I hope that both you and the Minister believe that the Opposition is very sincere in its endeavours in relation to this Bill. We believe we have a right, as I think the government has a right, to protect the workers of Australia. In the case of failed companies, it is usually not the workers fault that the company fails. Other people might put forward a countervailing argument, but in almost every case of company failure in Australia it could never be that the guilt would be sheeted to the employees. Almost always it has been the fault of the management or perhaps the economy generally that a company has failed, but certainly not the fault of the employees. How in heaven's name could anyone suggest that when a company does fail and employees are put out of work they cannot receive wages owing to them unless they are placed right at the bottom of the priorities list? I hope that the Minister would heed those remarks. I hope that, when the Ministerial Council discusses this Bill, the Opposition's amendment will be listened to and invoked.
