Title: PAIRS
text: Mr Millar)-Is the amendment seconded?

Speaker: Mrs CHILD
Title: PAIRS
text: Henty) (9.53)-Yes, I second the amendment. I do so very strongly. I think that the plight of the employee when the firm by which he is employed goes broke is pretty deplorable. Recently several firms in Melbourne, particularly manufacturing firms, have collapsed and a receiver has been appointed. In each case several hundred employees were immediately out of work, and with little warning. I will return to that aspect later. However, their plight is even worse than that of persons who are sacked or rendered redundant because in those cases people at least receive payment for the weeks they have worked, plus a week's notice with pay. Those men and women who have given their services and fulfilled their contracts with the firm concerned not only did not receive the pay that they were waiting for, which was probably needed to pay the rent and buy groceries, but also did not receive a week's notice pay, long service leave pro rata payments and holiday pay. The employees are way down the line as regards the priorities list. What happens when a firm goes broke, firstly, is that the secured creditors receive first call on the available finance followed closely by the Taxation Office, which we all seem to have a bogy about. It collects the accumulated pay-as-you-earn instalments. In the cases which I outlined this amounted to thousands of dollars. Another matter that I would like to know is why does the Taxation Office allow firms that are getting a bit rocky to owe it such tremendous amounts of money? In fact, in their final gasp, those firms are trying to float on employees' deductions. Then the companies go broke, that money goes too. The Taxation Office takes another bite in claiming tax on the undistributed dividends and then a third bite on tax on interest remitted overseas. Then the unsecured creditors are entitled to receive their share. We still have not reached the employees because nine categories of unsecured creditors come first. The workers run fifth. I find it quite unacceptable that unsecured creditors are placed ahead of employees on the list because unsecured creditors become involved after the winding up of a company. The employee was owed the money before the receiver came in. These debts were incurred after the winding up and the receiver was brought in, but the unsecured creditors still get paid before the debtors with whom the firm incurred liability before it became insolvent. If it were a horse race the workers certainly would run unplaced. The Crown must abrogate all Crown priorities in insolvency cases in line with the amendment which has been moved by the Opposition. As my colleague the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown) has pointed out, the Taxation Office certainly has plenty of other ways in which it can recoup its money. The employee cannot. I take the point which was made about the registered mortgage being applied against assets, but I again point out that the worker has invested his or her labour and I believe that his or her security is of prime importance no matter what is happening within the firm. If a person works for money it has become his or her money. Most firms know that they are going bankrupt while the employees are still working for them. It is quite immoral for firms to keep employees working when the management knows that they will not be paid at the end of that month, fortnight, or whenever the final crash comes. The rights of the worker in regard to payment for services given should receive the first protection. All wages and compensation payments to employees must be given priority over all other creditors. Maybe we need to have a reclassification of employees to place them in the first group, which is the secured creditors. r think that is where the employees belong. I cannot say too strongly that the Opposition believes that we have a moral and legal right to protect the wages of those who work. We were disappointed that the Government accepted the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in regard to Crown priorities. The Government did not go into a huddle with the States to get the States to agree that the Taxation Office should get out of the way and let the secured creditors and the workers take their bites before it received its share. In one of the cases which I referred to, something like $170,000 is owing to the Taxation Office. 1 think that the Department will have to waive that money because it should never have let the debt get to that extraordinary amount. It is important to realise that the employee has no other recourse for reimbursement. If he cannot get paid out of the funds, that is it. He cannot go to the man to whom he owes the rent or the person to whom he is paying the mortgage on his house and say: '1 worked for a month but 1 did not get paid'. Nobody will let him ofr the hook for what he owes. 1 urge the Government to accept this amendment which is on behalf of the workers. The Government and the Opposition in this place represent the people of Australia who are the workers.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: Ryan-Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (9.59)-Listening to the comments which have been made on the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill, one would think that the Commonwealth had done nothing towards it. In fact, that is far from the case. The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs did not say that secured creditors should come first on the priority list and then employees. It simply said that by abolishing Crown priorities the position of employees was improved because so much more money was left in the pool. By making that contribution, completely without the agreement of the States, we have made a contribution towards the general list of creditors on the scale. I think that this form of legislation has made a contribution. In the eyes of some, it may not have gone far enough, but certainly it has made a contribution along the right path. Earlier I took issue with the honourable member for Henty ( Mrs Child) in relation to certain creditors. On this occasion I have to take issue with the honourable member on the question of the costs incurred after the appointment. Quite naturally costs will be incurred as part of the ongoing operation after the receiver takes up his position. It is quite natural for those costs to be charged to the operation. The receiver would not accept the job if he did not receive a salary. Turning to the question of taxation collections, the Income Tax Assessment Act states that the employer has a responsibility to pay employees as soon as the deductions have been made and I know that there are certain penalties for those employers who do not. The responsibility for noncollection and for not following up lies with certain people. I support the priorities set down in this Bill. Title: AYES
text: Parramatta) (10.9)On behalf of the Opposition, I move: That Part III, comprising clauses 10 and 11, be omitted. These clauses remove the prohibitions on crossings by brokers acting for an offeror either on or off market. The Government indicates in its explanatory memorandum on this Bill, although the Viner,R.I. ·White,P.N.D. Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr Moore) made no mention of the matter in his second reading speech, the following: NOES Part III of the Bill will not be proclaimed to come into operation until the Ministerial Council agrees unanimously to do so. Before deciding to proclaim Part III, the Ministerial Council will consider: (a) reports on whether stock exchange business rules need changes to deal adequately with conflicts of interest during crossings; and (b) draft changes to the securities industry code relating to the enforcement of the relevant stock exchange business rules and appropriate disciplinary procedures for dealers. The Opposition objects to these amendments Scott,J.L. on two grounds. Firstly, as I mentioned in my Tbeophanous, A. C. speech on the motion that the Companies Bill be read a second time, what the Government is asking this Parliament to do is to pass into law provisions that we do not yet know are desirable or feasible. The Government is asking us to abrogate our responsibility and to hand over the decision to a body which is accountable to no one parliament. We consider this to be a breach of parliamentary processes which are all too often treated with contempt by this Government. Our second objection relates to the fact that we have no confidence that the business rules of the stock exchanges or, indeed, the policing capacity of these exchanges is adequate to deal with conflicts of interest during crossings. For example, we observe that the exchange in Sydney as reported in the Press on 8 May saw fit to fine an unnamed stockbroker $10,000 last week for malfeasance in dealing with a parcel of the dreaded Negri River Corporation Ltd shares. Strangely enough the broker's name has not been revealed. We figure this to be a weakness in the Companies Bill whereby the stock exchange can take unto itself the regulation of the activities and the behaviour of the brokers within that exchange. A person can be dealing, as this gentleman obviously had, dishonestly with a parcel of shares, can be fined $10,000 by that stock exchange and his name not be revealed to the Press. This gentleman, being a peer of the establishment, a pillar of society or whatever, is nothing more than a common criminal. There is something inherently wrong in this Bill where the stock exchange does not have the capacity, the right or, indeed, the intention of revealing this man's name in public. If he had been a shoplifter pinching a seven and sixpenny toy from Woolworths his name would have been revealed to the Press. But it appears that there is one law for the unwary and one law for the rich. We consider that Part III of this Bill which we would like omitted is a very weak arrangement. 1 know that the Minister has varying views from the Opposition on the subject of crossings. Perhaps he will give us the benefit of his wisdom in a moment or two. He cannot deny the inherent weakness of this Bill, in that the self-regulating policies stock exchange are like the self-regulating policies of anything else-nobody is competent to judge himself fairly and objectively. I suggest to the Minister that we hope that Part III of this Bill will be eliminated from the total Bill because we consider that it points up inherent weaknesses in the Bill. We consider that this whole area needs redrafting. Before 1 conclude, since this is the last time 1 will be speaking for the Opposition on this total great package of Bills, 1 think it would be reasonable to pay some sort of tribute to the Minister's staff sitting up there in the wings. They have been particularly helpful to the Opposition. The Minist¢r has fully made them available to us. That fact is appreciated by us. We thank them for their co-operation.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: AYES
text: Ryan-- Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs) (10.16)-1 would also like to thank those who participated in this debate, particularly the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown) and the honourable member for Hawker ( Mr Jacobi) who very obviously have made a considerable study of what has been in the Bills and have gone out of their way to inform themselves on a matter which does not really entice a lot of people to take much notice of. I commend them for the effort they have put into it and certainly for the knowledge that they have imparted during the debate tonight. It is a very helpful contribution to what I hope will be a fairly memorable occasion insofar as it is the first time in Australia's history that we have had a national companies Bill passed by the national Parliament. In relation to crossings, 1 hate to inform the honourable member for Parramatta that the man not named by the Stock Exchange was not involved in a crossings problem. Nevertheless, this case does bear out some of the migivings that people have with the Stock Exchange as a whole. What people really need to do is to brush up on their public relations and to see far more of their public responsibilities. I will say something about crossings because this is one of those areas where very few people have an idea of what it is all about. There is plenty of recrimination and plenty of saying: 'It's all wrong'. But there is no great background of understanding what it is about. The term 'crossing' simply means a sale within a broker's office, that is, broker to broker and from client to client. In those circumstances a relationship develops between a client and a broker in exactly the same way as between a patient and a doctor. The most important thing to of the anyone, after health, is a person's shares or money. 1 think everyone in this place and some of those who have gone will probably recognise that. Because of that the relationships between a broker and his client are particularly close. I go on to the next stage because most of the problems appear to be in the area of crossings associated with an offer. An offer is made for a company and is well publicised in the Press. that Notice of the offer is posted on the boards of the stock exchange. Those brokers who are dealing in a stock not only are presumed to have read the newspapers but also are presumed to have read the notices on the boards within the stock exchange. So, on two counts they are adjudged to know of the offer. Under those circumstances a client who is a client of the broker acting for the offeror who wishes to sell his shares then approaches his broker with that order to sell. He is offering his shares for sale in the knowledge of the offer because it is advised in the newspapers. The broker knows about it because he has read about it in the newspapers. If he has not, that notice is on the board on the floor of the Stock Exchange where the deal must take place and, as a consequence, he is informed. Therefore, in my view a crossing within the full knowledge of both the buyer and the seller is quite within the bounds of commercial activity and quite within the rules of the stock exchange. Mr Jacobi---But the rules of the stock exchange are defective in that case.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: AYES
text: They are not at all. I am surprised that the honourable member for Hawker seems not to understand that these are transactions taking place in a fully informed market. Mr John Brown--What about before the offer is made public?

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: AYES
text: The honourable member for Parra matt a has raised a point. 1 think I told him about this in the corridor. That problem can only really take place where a broker is building up a holding on behalf of an offeror prior to the offer being made. Under the circumstances of the new Bill dealing with the National Companies and Securities Commission that relates to shares prior to the 20 per cent threshold. Under those circumstances a broker acting for an offeror accumulating up to the 20 per cent mark on a rising market will, of course, be buying shares at a varying price. A client of that broker offering to sell on those price patterns needs to know of these activities or have complete trust in that broker. It is only within that context that J see a problem within the prospect of crossings. I take the view that most brokers are honest. I take the view that most clients trust the activities of their broker. As I have said before, we are dealing with a person's most precious commodity-his money. Therefore, I say that it would be a very silly broker who acted not with the best interests of his client at heart despite the fact that he could be acting for an offeror. I can only say that in a position like that the broker is more likely to say to his client: 'Hold on, there is something coming', and to advise him quietly that there is something better coming and that he ought to hold on on that occasion. J do not hold these enormous fears for crossings. T think there is a lot in the relationship between the individual client and his broker. Within the game of the financial world there is an enormous amount of personal trust and integrity which undoubtedly prevails in the very marked majority of cases throughout Australia. Second Reading Mr MILTON (La Trobe) (10.30)-1I have referred very briefly in the past to the issue of gun clubs. I wish to return to this issue tonight. The gun lobby is made up of many different gun clubs in the country' and the firearms traders. I reiterate that I am in no way opposed to gun clubs or to the legitimate training and practice in the correct use of firearms. But the problem of noise cause by the Third Reading gun club activities in residential areas is a serious one in my electorate. I want to refer to the Lysterfield Range which affects my constituents in the Belgrave Heights area. Because of extensive change in land use patterns in this area since 1970 when the lease was signed, the gun club now poses severe nuisance value in the area. The number of houses has increased to such an extent that the gun club is now in a residential area. Noise from Second Reading this range is so bad, and occurs on both weekdays and for many hours at the weekend, that residents frequently have to leave their homes and go out for the day. Residents have taken local action themselves to try to solve this problem, but have been totally unsuccessful. In fact, with the increasing membership of the club, there is now 2352 REPRESENTATIVES more noise, from more shoots, and the gun club plans to extend even further. A local residents action group committed itself to $2,000 worth of sound readings taken by one of Melbourne's most reputable firms. On four occasions in the past few months the readings showed excessive noise at seven different properties throughout the area. Some readings have been taken inside the living rooms of homes and noise levels are such that, under the Australian Standard Specification, there would be immediate community and personal reaction. An expert report to the Shire of Sherbrooke from the Environmental Protection Authority and professional sound consultants last October, stated that: 'from the results of the survey, it is clear that, at present, the Range is imposing an intolerable burden on nearby residents, and we do not believe this should continue.' There can be no doubt that such noise levels are having a detrimental effect on land values in the area. The local Sherbrooke Shire Council has requested that the gun club take action to lower noise levels, but has found no improvement in noise levels and frequency eminating from the range. It has now resorted to supreme court action on the matter, which involves considerable time, effort and expense from a local council to be involved in. The action has been deemed essential because no relief has been possible through government channels. This is a very real problem to local residents, and is causing severe distress and costing them many thousands of dollars as their home investment is devalued. While I appreciate the need for gun clubs, this particular problem shows that there is a vital need for such organisations to keep in touch with the realities of residential life. I suggest that an inquiry into the location and nature of gun clubs in the whole of Australia would reveal similar problems in other parts of the country. There is a need to establish a uniform set of standards for the zoning and positioning of these ranges and to remove them from proximity to residential areas. The other aspect of the use of firearms which concerns me is the increased use of such weapons for political and criminal terrorism, as illustrated in the recent assassination of John Lennon in New York and the attempted assassination of President Reagan. Whilst we have not yet reached the stage in this country where our political and other leaders are threatened and killed, and where 200 million guns are in private hands with little or any control over them, as in the United States, the Australian situation is rapidly moving in this direction. 13 May 1981 Adjournment i According to Professor Richard Harding, whose book Firearms and Violence in Australian Life has just been published, we are well on the way to reaching the American situation. He describes the domestic gun scene in Australia as 'destructive, volatile, self perpetuating and intractable'. Our political leaders, when asked to comment on events such as the Reagan assassination attempt, claimed smugly that our laws are much tighter here. This may be so. However, the eight Australian police commissioners have pointed out that, through a loophole in regulations, the Israeli Uzi machine pistols and the Russian Kalashnikov assault rifles can be readily imported into this country. This type of weapon is used by terrorists and armed criminals throughout the world. It is favoured by private armies in many countries. In the context of the increasing dangers to society from all types of firearms, no tightening of regulations would be too severe. The Federal Government must act to ensure that what has happened in the United States of America cannot happen here. Uniform and stringent federal regulations on the use and possession of firearms by individuals and organisations is vitally necessary.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES
text: O'Connor) (10.34)-It will be interesting to consider and comment on the speech which has been made in view of the advice that is often given by honourable members on the other side of the House. In the circumstances which have been mentioned it is a wonder that the constituents were not advised to go and stand in front of the guns. However, I rise on a different matter tonight. In his statement to the House on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced the intention to sell certain commercially-oriented assets. I applaud this announcement. The Opposition denounces it and, in fact, declares it will repurchase any assets sold. I presume it will arbitrarily resume such property purely on the grounds that it was once the property of the Commonwealth. Let us hope this socialistic principle is not to be applied to all other property owners in the Australian Capital Territory. The Opposition further sees this suggestion as being a move to benefit big business in allowing it the opportunity of financial returns on what were government initiatives. This need not be so. One of the properties concerned is the Belconnen Mall. If honourable members think it is peculiar for a Western Australian to speak on this issue, I think that the silence from the honourable member for Canberra ( Mrs Kelly) and the honourable member for Fraser ( Mr Fry) warrants some comments in this House. The Belconnen Mall has a total lettable area of 520,000 square feet. The Mall has 172 separate shops. These vary in size from the Myer Canberra store which is 220,000 square feet to a store of 100 square feet. The four major stores-Myer, G. J. Coles and Co. Ltd, K Mart (Australia) Ltd and Woolworths Ltd-collectively occupy 360,000 square feet while a typical small trader occupies 800 square feet. The tenants of these shops pay rent to the Commonwealth based on their turnover. In other words, all charges to their customers must include this figure. There can be no economy of scale reflected in lower prices. The tenants have their own association. It met last week to discuss a proposal for the strata titling of the mall. Of the 172 tenants, 118 were represented. They voted unanimously to approach the Government to arrange a strata titles deal and to offer the various shops to the tenants in the first instance. I support this concept entirely. If I need support from the Government, might I quote from the Prime Minister's statement. On page one of his statement, he referred to 'increased opportunities for all'. On page 2, he said: And we must not forget that it is people, their knowledge and their talents, their enterprise lief that they can succeed, who have built Australia. I support the concept of small government. I equally support the concept of small business. I have ample experience to say that it achieves efficiencies far in excess of big business and creates an enthusiasm to succeed impossible in the impartial corridors of big business. The Government now has a tremendous opportunity to demonstrate its principles of support for private enterprise and support for the individual by sale of the Belconnen Mall to its tenants. Some will say the administrative difficulties make it impossible. I remind them that Columbia has orbitted the earth and returned unscathed. Some will say the large tenants policy is not to purchase freehold and that certain small tenants will be unable to finance purchase of their section. This could certainly occur. However, it is no deterrent to strata titling. Such areas as are not purchased by their occupiers can be made available to other investors small and large. If we consider the range of areas and consequently variation in purchase prices that will be on offer, it is obvious the type of investors interested in lease back will be considerable. What will the new owneroperator and his customers gain? With fixed capital charges, the tenant will naturally address himself to maximising the turnover of his area. Increased turnover will improve the capital value of his property and reduce the effect of capital charges on his mark-up. The resulting reduced prices will benefit his customers and presumably increase his turnover further. That is Liberal philosophy at work. At the successful completion of this project, a similar approach should be considered at our airport terminals. The 'ownerdriver' whatever his actual business activity-he might be a contract carpenter, a truck driver or a small shop owner-is the backbone of the Australian economy. I request the Government to take up the challenge at Belconnen and to support this principle. When the sales are completed to those sturdy traders, I challenge the Opposition to try to take them back.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES
text: Hunter) (10.39)-A short time ago, I made reference to the decreasing real value of the total grants that have been made available to the States since this Government first came to office in 1975-76. I indicated on that occasion that I would take the opportunity to pursue the matter further and to explain the developments that have taken place, not only in relation to the total grants being made available to the States, but also, more particularly, to the effect that the States have experienced as a result of the policies of this Government in relation to their and determination, their begeneral purpose capital grants and their specific purpose grants. On that previous occasion I referred to the fact that during the current year in real terms the total States grants are deficient to the extent of $1,418m compared with the amount the States received in total in 1975-76. I also referred to a statement made by the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Sir Phillip Lynch), at the Liberal Party's New South Wales council meeting in Maitland in March this year. At that conference the Minister also said: The States can expect little joy from Commonwealth decisions in the short months ahead. It is becoming increasingly apparent exactly what that statement means. The most recent spectacle was the States' being denied the $70m that both the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) had been authorised by Cabinet to allow to them. Following that, we saw the public humiliation of the States throughout the whole of the Commonwealth. We saw a very serious reaction from the States when they realised the extent to which they had been conned, the reasons they had been conned and the way in which both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer paraded themselves before the media to show how strong and clever they had been, not only at the expense of the State Premiers and State governments, but also at the expense of the residents in the States. I wish to develop further the points I made previously in relation to grants. First of all, I will deal specifically with the general purpose capital funds allocated to the States. In 1975-76 general purpose capital funds to the States totalled $1,291m. In the current financial year, 1980-81, general purpose capital funds to the States total $1,307m. That represents an increase during those five years of only 1.2 per cent. In order to maintain their real value in terms of what has happened to costs and prices during that period, they should have increased by 63.4 per cent or $818m. The actual increase that has taken place in those capital funds has not been anything like the $818m necessary in order to retain their real value. They have increased by only $16m during those five years. That means that in this year alone general purpose capital funds to the States are deficient in real terms to the extent of $802m. The situation in relation to specific purpose payments is essentially the same. In 1975-76 the allocations to the States were $4, 152m. In the current year they are $5,227m. In other words, they have increased by 26 per cent. During that period prices have increased by 63.4 per cent. If specific purpose payments to the States had maintained their real value, they would have increased by $2,632m. In fact, the actual increase was $1 ,075m. Therefore, in this year alone, specific purpose payments to the States are deficient in real terms to the extent of $1 ,567m. The substance and the import of the statements made by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Trade and Resources ( Mr Anthony) are becoming increasingly apparent to the States. There has been a very well orchestrated campaign on the part of the Government to squeeze the States and to put them into a position of being seriously disadvantaged.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES
text: Mallee) (10.44)-I am quite sure that every honourable member in this House recognises that the provision of adequate and suitable housing is a crucial element in the successful development of our communities. In the electorate of Mallee, over the last three or four years, we have seen very significant growth in both economic activity and the creation of additional population. In the city of Mildura, which without doubt is one of the finest provincial cities in Australia, this has been indicated by a 28 per cent increase in the issue of housing permits for private dwellings over the last two years. I believe this is an indication of the Government's success in stimulating real growth and creating real opportunities for long term employment. Of course, it has developed a real confidence in the future viability of our rural and provincial cities. However, T believe it is recognised that housing is a limiting factor in the development of population growth. Without doubt, in every community in my electorate--this would be so in almost every electorate throughout Australia-housing is a limiting factor. Almost every area needs additional skilled tradesmen. Small communitie- are unable to obtain skilled tradesmen if housing is not avail" able. Seasonal employment opportunities throughout the north-west part of Victoria attract hundreds of people every year to that region. Of course, because of the friendly nature of the people and the opportunities for work, they stay. EmptyHere

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES
text: As the honourable member for Barker correctly stated, they stay also because of the friendly nature of their local member. If we are to house these people successfully and to keep them in our rural communities, large appropriations vf funds to the housing area are needed. I am, therefore, very pleased to hear of the importance this Government attaches-lam sure all Opposition members would agree-to efficiency in our administration. We now live in an age of superior technology. The silicon chip and computers have become a necessary part of any efficient cost effective organisation. The recent findings of the Review of Commonwealth Functions have shown us that departments have to move towards cost efficiency. In his statement to the House, the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced that every effort will be made to eliminate nonefficient services, to combine common service areas, to make more efficient use of automatic data processing and to decentralise and deregulate management decisions to individual departments. The Department of Housing and Construction is moving in this direction by acquiring a computer network to ensure efficient delegation of activities. This network requires a central computer with facilities in each region. It will be a link behyeen the central and regional operations. This is a crucial part in the efficient operation of the network. It was one of the main determinants of the Government's decision to acquire the network from IBM Australia Ltd. Criticism of the Government's decision fails to recognise this crucial element. I believe it demonstrates a complete failure by the Opposition to appreciate the importance of ensuring the best equipment for the job.

Speaker: Mr FRY
Title: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES
text: Fraser) (10.49)-1 was interested to hear the honourable member for O'Connor ( Mr Tuckey) who apparently has become an instant expert on the Belconnen Mall. I wonder whether that is true or whether he was merely reading a speech prepared for him by the Minister for the Capital Territory ( Mr Hodgman). It should be known that the Belconnen shopping mall is an outstanding project. It is unique in that it is the only publicly owned shopping mall. It has been very successful. It was about to divert its profits to provide recreational facilities for the people of Belconnen who have been neglected by the Government. Whilst my favoured proposal is that the mall should remain public property, I would certainly prefer it to be sold under strata title than to one of the friends of the Government. Time will tell. I wish to speak briefly tonight about the letter which, I think, all honourable members received from the National President of the Returned Services League of Australia in which he made accusations against an organisation called Women Against Rape. The letter stated: The RSL learned of their plans which were as follows: 1. to bring to Canberra as many members of their group as possible to participate. 2. to march no matter what and carry placards representing the various groups forming part of the women marching, for example, 'Wimmin Against Rape' and 'Women Against Nuclear Energy'. 3. to effectively 'reduce the militarism of the march' by slashing the drums of the bands participating, by damaging their instruments, with paint. They planned to make the bands in the march their major target. 4. to obstruct the march ing veterans so that the veterans would have to walk over them symbolising 'rape'. 5. to deface the Australian War Memorial. It should be noted that last year sons unknown' but this year the War Memorial in Perth was desecrated. These are the hysterical accusations which the RSL and the Minister have made against this women's organisation in Canberra. I just want to read out the response which the organisation has sent to honourable members. It states: This letter is in response to accusations made against Women Against Rape by the RS.L., the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, and the Australian Federal Police. Women Against Rape would like to make it known, yet one more time, that it categorically denies all allegations against it that the group had at any time intended to disrupt the ANZAC Day march last month. We at no time even discussed the activities suggested (drum slashing, symbolically being walked over by the veterans etc. etc) even in jest, let alone decide to adopt them as tactics on ANZAC Day. From the first five minutes of the first meeting of the organising collective ment to non-violence. We went to great lengths non-violently if we were confronted by violence from the police or spectators. All our meetings were open to any woman who wished to attend; all our decisions were made public through leaflets, letters, media releases and word-ofmouth. Workshops, open to any woman wishing to attend were publicized and run. In these, role playing and discussion were used to help women to prepare themselves to respond non-violently. We are happy to make available to you minutes of all our meetings and all documents relating to our collective. On ANZAC morning we gathered as planned, marching off silently and in an orderly fashion (after yet again stressing our commitment to non-violence) to join the end of the official march without disruption. The rest of the story is well known. We were stopped and arrests resulted, police using the amended traffic ordinance gazetted for the occasion. There was no disruption to the official ANZAC parade and it should be noted that the six busloads of interstate women we were supposedly importing for the occasion were nowhere to be seen. Only one-tenth of the sixty one women arrested were from interstate. Neither did any of the women arrested have spray cans of paint, implements with which to slash drums, or anything else, with which to create a disturbance, on their persons. The RSL, the Minister and the police based their hysterical stand to disallow us marching on what they say was the evidence of an informant. As we know that no such incriminating discussions ever took place we must believe that, either this informant never existed and that the Minister and the RSL are lying, or that if she did exist she lied to them. If the latter is the case, the RSL, the Minister and the police must take responsibility for refusing over three hundred women their rights of free expression on the spurious evidence of one, as yet, unidentified woman. Of course, it is not mentioned that it may have been a man dressed in drag. The letter continues: and by spraying the bandsmen Women Against Rape is at present looking into our legal position in relation to the slanderous and libelous comments made by the Mirtister and the RSL. by laying down in front of marchMONICA

Speaker: Mr COLEMAN
Title: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES
text: Wentworth) (10.54)-1 ' want to draw the attention of the House to the grievance of an organisation which is based in my the Memorial was defaced by 'perelectorate but which speaks for the broken families of Poles and in particular of Polish refugees who have settled in Australia. This is the Committee for Family Reunions, whose address is Post Office Box 104, Woollahra. I am sure that the House is aware that in the last year or two some 2,000 to 3,000 Polish refugees have come to Australia, joining the 120,000 or so Poles who settled here in earlier years. At least 400 of these Poles are husbands who are separated from their wives and children and who have sought unsuccessfully over months and years to get permission levelled for their wives and children who are living in Poland to join them in Australia. They are obviously being punished by the Polish Government for having left Poland because Poland does not recognise the right of emigration. But worse than that, they are being harassed in in January, there was a commitAustralia and their families are being harassed into prepare ourselves, to respond Poland. It has been reported by this Committee that some of those who are living in Australia are encouraged or asked to become snoopers on other Polish refugees and to report their activities to the Polish Consulate. Others are ridiculed on the grounds that their wives do not want to join them, despite all the evidence to the contrary. Mr Boniecki, who is a spokesman for the Australian Committee for Human Rights in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, stated: We have the case of one man whose wife and three-year-old son were refused permission to leave Poland three times. When this man approached the Polish Consul in Sydney at a public function, the Consul and publicly declared that everyone want to join him. Consequently, to prove the man has obtained a statutory declaration certified by a Polish court that his wife wants to leave the country. Of course, there has been no change in the attitude of the Po1ish Consul or of the Warsaw Government. These men are being punished for having left Poland, despite the fact that Poland signed the Helsinki Agreement on Human Rights in 1975, not to mention the Universal Declaration on Human Rights of the United Nations. It has refused to issue passports. It has refused this fundamental right. Some delay in the processing of these matters is understandable. It would not be surprising if it took some weeks or in certain cases some months, but this has taken many months and is going on into years. Late last year the Australian Committee for Human Rights in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe sent a telegram to the Conference on European Security and Co-operation in Madrid. The telegram stated: Attention of the Conference is drawn to the specific situation of spouses and children of hundreds of Polish refugees recently settled in Australia. repeatedly refused passports so that they can leave Poland and be reunited with their families in Australia. Please press the Polish authorities to respect these basic human rights in the spirit of the Helsinki Agreements and to allow these families to leave immediately. There has been no response from Poland. There has certainly been a response in Australia. There have been hunger strikes. There is a fear that there will be more serious responses by these people in Australia who have been unable to bring their wives and children-in some cases very young children-from Poland. We know that the Polish Government is divided. We know that there are hard liners who want the Soviet Union to occupy the country in the manner of Czechoslovakia in the 1960s. We also know that there are others who take a more progressive line. There are some in Australia who would say that we should not be embarrassing the Polish Government in the present situation, but it seems to me that it is so simple a matter for the progressive element in the Polish Government to agree to give passports to those families that we should be pressing them. The Polish Government could do one simple thing to earn the sympathy of Australians and that is allow these families to be reunited. text: Batman) (10.59)-1 want to draw attention briefly to a petition which 1 presented yesterday on behalf of a co-operative group in the north-west of Tasmania known as TARGA. That group collected 2,500 signatures concerning the issue of plant breeders' rights. The group holds very strong views about the subject. It is concerned about the proposed legislation, which will restrict free growing and the exchange and sale of non-chemically treated seeds, and believes that a decline in the genetic diversity of plants was evidenced in Europe following the implementation of such legislation. The group believes that it is important that this issue be canvassed in full scale public debate. I believe that the group would argue that there are several reasons why the plant breeders' rights legislation ought to be opposed. It would argue, firstly, that seeds are a public resource; secondly, that seed patenting effectively allows large corporations to control seed production and sales; and, thirdly, that germ plasm, the basic seed used in breeding programs, is hoarded by these corporations and exchanges of seed and scientific information slow down. 1 beThese families still in Poland are lieve that this point of view that this group is seeking to disseminate is important. 1 think it is unfortunate that sometimes all the work that goes into collecting signatures for petitions is given such brief attention in the House. 1 just wanted to place on record in the time available the fact that this group had done the work and that there were so many signatures on the petition and to draw attention to the substance of the petition.

Title: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES
text: Darling Downs-Minister for Housing and Construction) (ll.O)- Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to speak on comments made during the adjoutnment debate by the honourable member for Mallee ( Mr Fisher) who highlighted the need for computer technology as a tool for efficient government administration. At the outset I want to say that I wholeheartedly endorse his sentiments. I thank him very much indeed for a thoughtful contribution to the adjournment debate. It is always good when someone raises his thought to matters of national importance rather than parish pump activities. My Department of course has immense communication and administration requirements which have made its computer purchase essential. I agree with the honourable member that criticism of computers fails to appreciate the tremendously important role they play and the importance of the link between the central and regional facilities in any computer network. In regard to my own Department the Government decided on the successful tenderer for the supply of its equipment after the Department's own very thorough evaluation process had been reviewed by an expert interdepartmental committee on the technical and procurement aspects of the purchase and later on by an independent assessor, Professor C. H. Brookes. These studies confirmed the original finding that the substantially higher technical risks associated with alternative solutions could not be accepted, The Government is satisfied that the expert reviews carried out have ensured the best possible solution to meet the needs of the Department of Housing and Construction. Assertions have been made that the Government had changed its tendering criteria and my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services ( Mr Newman) has previously refuted this allegation and commented on procurement principles. Perhaps the most extensive refutation of these allegations comes from the Australian General Manager of Sperry Univac-an unsuccessful tender. The Melbourne branch manager of that company was quoted as being critical of the tendering process. The Australian General Manager of that company inserted an advertisement at his company's expense the following week completely refuting those claims. The Australian General Manager has said he is the only person who can authorise official media releases for the company. The official media release includes the statement: Over the past few months ports by the media concerning a tender for the data requirements for the Department of Housing and Construction, Canberra, culminating in comments and statements made in a report on page 1 of the Pacific Computer Weekly of 23-29 January 1981. All official media releases for my company are authorised from the General Manager's Office at Sperry Univac. As the above mentioned comments that were published were not authorised by me, I must refute the opinons and statements so published on this subject. Sperry Univac's association with governments, both Federal and State, is conducted on a professional basis, with the supply of equipment and services to them being of the highest possible standard. At all times Sperry Univac has received the respected assistance, courtesy and advice from all government departments. We have always found the actions of various government members to be of the highest professional standard. As honourable members will be aware, there have been many attempts to criticise my Department's computer purchase. Attempts were made on 8 September 1980 at the House of Representatives Committee on Expenditure; in this chamber on three occasions during September 1980; and in the Pacific Computer Weekly of 23-29 January 1981. I regret to say that in this chamber today yet another attempt was made to criticise that purchase and to criticise and question the integrity of the Public Service and the tendering processes which were followed in the computer procurement. I hope that this restatement of the facts will put these unfounded allegations to rest once and for all. I resent the aspersions cast on the integrity of officers of my Department who are men of outstanding ability, honesty and sincerity of purpose. These aspersions were cast earlier today by the honourable member for Reid ( Mr U ren).

This report, which was released on 2 February 1981, recommends that the Govern the prosment should vigorously encourage the development of alternative liquid fuels, but that commercial criteria should be applied to any decision to produce these fuels on a significant scale. Social Welfare Supplementary Assistance Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 February 1981: (1) Further to the Minister's reply to question No. 142 (Hansard, 4 December 1980, page 470), by how much has the cost of average rental accommodation increased since the last increase to supplementary assistance was made on 14 November 1974. (2) Is it a fact that the cost of Queensland Housing Commission rental accommodation has increased from $16.25 per week in June 1974 to approximately $45 per week in June 1980. (3) Will the Government give serious consideration to increasing the supplementary assistance in line with inflation in rents as indicated by increases in State Housing Commission rents; if not, why not.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) The private housing rent component of the Consumer Price Index increased by 71 per cent between the December quarters of 1974 and 1980 and the government housing component by 198 per cent. However, on average, government rents are still much lower than private rents, as shown by the recently published Australian Bureau of Statistics Survey of Housing Occupancy and Costs, Australia, August 1980, which estimated that, at the survey date, the average weekly rent of houses in State capital cities was $32.43 in the case of government landlords and $56.17 in the case of private landlords (other than the individual's employer). (2) These rent levels are determined by the Queensland Housing Commission. Recent policy is that they be marketrelated. It is my understanding that the rents quoted by the honourable member are broadly correct and reflect rents charged by the Commission for three-bedroom houses. (3) The level of supplementary assistance is determined in relation to other priorities in the Budget context. Although changes in rent levels are a factor to be considered in assessing the levels of this supplement for rent paying pensioners with little or no private income, it should be noted that pensioners (Question No. 604) and beneficiaries who are tenants" of State-Housing Commissions may avail themselves of the assistance provided by those authorities by way of rental rebates or rent reductions. Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) I am advised by my Department that action has been taken by the ACT Advisory Committee for IYDP to encourage the involvement of all parts of our community in assisting disabled persons and is already well advanced. This has included, with the co-operation of the Confederation of ACT Industry, fostering of awareness and support of IYDP by way of an employer education programme directed to some 1,400 outlets. On an even broader plane through the Advisory Committee's Newsletter 'Delta', organisations and individuals are being encouraged to develop projects designed to assist disabled persons and to seek advice and assistance where that is needed. The Assistance to Inventors Scheme administered by my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology, serves as an excellent means of encouraging individual initiative and provides for financial assistance, by way of a grant, of up to $10,000 for development of anyone project including the support and testing of prototypes of inventions. Aids to assist disabled persons are covered by this scheme. (2) A number of requests have been received by the Advis(Question No. 741) ory Committee Secretariat in recent months for funding to assist the development of innovative projects aimed at assisting disabled persons in the ACT community-surveillance devices to safeguard autistic children, alarms to assist blind and visually impaired people crossing traffic intersections and a wheelchair with special features, for the physically disabled. A grant of $700 has already been paid to the autistic Children's Association of the ACT vices Programme allocation to mark IYDP, to assist the development of various items of prototype equipment. A number of other inventions are being mittee for possible funding. (3) As I have indicated, a well established scheme designed to encourage and support inventions operates at a national level. ACT inventors have access to that scheme. No funds have been set aside in the ACT specifically to assist the development of technical aids and equipment for disabled persons. (6) What published studies does the Minister rely on to form his assessments of trends markets in the 1980's.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as fonows: (1) Yes. (2) and (3) The generally accepted view among aluminium indusry experts is that the United States aluminium market has a considerable influence on the fortunes of the aluminium industry throughout the world, including the international alumina market. However, it would be misleading to attribute (Question No. 840) the decision by Alcoa of Australia directly to a short-term downturn in United States demand for aluminium. According to a spokesman from Alcoa of Australia the decision was due to a softening of the international alumina market. Commodity markets are normally subject to cyclical influences on demand. In 1979 there was a marked world shortage of aluminium which resulted in a rapid run down of producers' stocks. Throughout 1980 stocks were replenished to normal levels. These influences resulted in aluminium producers running smelters at high capacity and alumina producers streamlining production facilities to produce additional tonnage. The current alumina over-supply, which is likely to persist into 1982 is partly a result of the above chain that the brain damage referred of events and partly a result of failure of the metal market to of copper and zinc levels sustain growth projections in the short term. Alcoa's decision is the result of the company's commercial judgement. According to the company's thinking, there would be little point in hastening such a project to completion before the market has returned to optimum conditions. I am not aware of other projects which may be delayed because of market factors. Taking both demand and supply factors into account, it is confidently predicted that the outlook for Australia's alumina and aluminium remains quite favourable and that any delays in completion of projects will be temporary. It is interesting to reflect that the construction of the Alcoa Pinjarra refinery was also undertaken in a situation of market downturn, but subsequent recovery in demand fully accommodated the tonnage produced. (4) Current indications are that both the US. and Japanese aluminium demand are expected to grow at about 5 per cent per annum over the coming decade although yearly variations are almost certain. (5) I am informed that alumina spot prices are substantially referred to, I am unable to combelow levels of 12 months ago. The true emergency group comprise of applicants who demonstrate an inability to accommodate themselves that night in any way whatsoever, ego because their home has been destroyed by fire. These few genuine emergency applicants can be accommodated on the same day. Other successful applicants for what is called emergency housing are those who can demonstrate that their circumstances are such that they would suffer undue hardship if required to wait out their time on the normal housing waiting period and therefore that an advance allocation ahead of all others on the normal waiting list is justified. The proposals, while in broad terms based on estimates submitted by departments, (Question No. 1066) followed Government consideration of those estimates in the light of its policies in respect of particular areas of expenditure and of general financial and economic objectives. The general principles applied to the preparation of estimates by departments and authorities are set out in the Directions issued by the Secretary of the Department of Finance under the authority of the Audit Act 1901. These Directions are long standing and have been endorsed by successive Governments. The relevant general principles are set out in Finance Direction 6.3 and provide in essence that: (i) Estimates shall represent a realistic assessment of the sums expected to be spent and shall be based on current or known costs. Items of a recurring nature may be estimated on the basis of experience. (ii) Estimates shall not include amounts in respect of proposals which are so far from firm that it is not possible to form any real estimate of what payment, if any, will be made. The Administration has said that it seeks repeal on principle because the amendment is a restriction on executive authority. (2) I have seen reports to this effect. :,-'pr (3) and (4) The United States Administration has said that its policy towards South Afrij:a is under review. President Reagan's nominee for the position of Under Secretary of State (Question No. 1119) for African Affairs, Mr Chester Crocker, has recently visited a number of countries in Europe and Africa, including Angola, for discussions as part of that review. Until the results of the review have been announced, it is not possible to judge what effects any new United States policy might have, but the Government notes that in testimony to the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee Mr Crocker said the United States Government did not intend to 'destabilize' the Government of Angola. Applied Ecology Pty Ltd: Turtle Seminar Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 9 April 1981: What action has the Government taken on the concern expressed at the Turtle Seminar conducted by Applied Ecology Pty Ltd in conjunction with the James Cook University in June 1979 at the large number of female turtles being harvested in the Torres Strait/Gulf of Papua area and the effects this harvesting is having on area. Mr Wilson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Internationally, marine turtles are considered to be threatened with extinction largely trolled commercial exploitation. Australian territorial waters contain some of the largest populations of marine turtles remaining in the world and the Government acknowledges its responsibility for ensuring these endangered species are adequately protected and managed in such a manner that will assure their long-term conservation. The Third Meeting of Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) held recently in New Delhi, considered and adopted Australian proposals to include two Australian species of marine turtle on Appendix I to the Convention. This has resulted in all marine turtles being listed on Appendix I to the Convention thereby prohibiting international commercial trade in products derived from them. Torres Strait Islanders have traditionally hunted marine 1977-78 1978-79 1979-80 turtles for food and subsistence. The Torres Strait between Australia and Papua New Guinea, while protecting the tra$ $ $ ditional way of life, including traditional fishing, also allows for the adoption of conservation measures in respect of endangered or threatened wildlife. The Government is concerned to ensure that its obligations under this Treaty and CITES are honoured. Following the closure of turtle farming activities in Torres Veterans' Affairs Strait by Applied Ecology Pty Ltd, the Australian National (Question No. 1840) Parks and Wildlife Service engaged the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service to undertake a pilot study. The objectives of this study are: to determine the need. for further detailed research on marine turtles in the region; and to determine the impact of subsistence harvesting on marine turtle numbers. The report of this preliminary study is expected early in the 1981-82 financial year. Mr Humphreys asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 April 1981: Are eligible applicants for sickness benefit who are in time employment as juniors and who are receiving substantially less than the usual sickness benefit under 18 year olds, entitled category, of $36 per week.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: HIGH COURT BUILDING
text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: No. The Social Services Act provides that the weekly rate of sickness benefit payable to a person cannot exceed the weekly rate of salary, wages or other income which that person has lost by reason of his incapacity. This means that if a claimant's loss of income is less than the maximum amount of sickness benefit, the rate of sickness benefit payable is limited to the claimant's actual loss of income.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: HIGH COURT BUILDING
text: On 24 March 1981 (Hansard, page 812) Mr Keating asked me a question, without notice, concerning royalties for Bass Strait oil. The following is in answer to the honourable employing authorities such as member's question: In accordance with the offshore petroleum legislation, royalties are assessed on the wellhead value which is determined by deducting from the selling price certain costs involved in the processing and transportation of the oil from the offshore platform to the selling point. Payments of crude oil excise are also deducted. Where crude oil excise is not payable, the wellhead value will be higher and royalty payments accordingly greater. The legislation provides for basic royalties to be shared 40 per cent to the Commonwealth and 60 per cent to the States. on the terms and conditions to The current arrangments for determining wellhead value in regard to Bass Strait production were agreed by the Commonwealth and Victoria. This joint approach will continue under the revised offshore petroleum arrangements when they become effective under the offshore constitutional settlement, but in the event of any irreconcilable difference the Commonwealth will have the final say. The current royalty sharing arrangements are to continue under the new legislative arrangments. Coastal Surveillance: Expenditure by Department of Transport

Title: HIGH COURT BUILDING
text: the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 24 February 1981: (1) What sum was (a) appropriated and (b) actually spent by his Department on coastal surveillance for (i) 1977-78, (ii) 1978-79 and (iii) 1979-80. (2) What were the main items of expenditure and the cost attributed to each item.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: HIGH COURT BUILDING
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) (a) During the period 1977-78, 1978-79 no specific sum was appropriated for coastal surveillance. Funds were included in appropriations to cover the total operations of my Department. In 1979-80 an amount of $1.5m was appropriated under Division 655/2/21 to finance the cost of evaluating Nomad aircraft for a role in coastal surveillance. No other funds were specifically appropriated. (b) The amounts actually spent on coastal surveillance are reflected in various items of Divisions 655/1 and 655/2 e.g. salaries, overtime, communications, etc. No expenditure was incurred under Division 655/2/21. (2) Except for Division 655/2/21 expenditure under each item attributable to coastal surveillance has not been determined because of the relatively minor nature of the coastal surveillance program compared with other Departmental activities. However an assessment of costs is being undertaken as part of the Government review of the coastal surveillance program. Department of Transport: Functions Mr MCLean asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 25 February 1981: What are the functions of the (a) Policy and Planning and (b) Surface Transport Operations areas of his Department.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: HIGH COURT BUILDING
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as following: (a) The functions of the Policy and Planning area of my Department are: Development of policies on the most effective allocation of resources among the various transport modes Encouragement and promotion of continuous socially acceptable improvement, innovation, growth and phase-out of modal and inter-modal commercial and personal transport Assistance in the formulation of policy for transport undertakings which are authorities of the Commonwealth Government or in which the Commonwealth is a shareholder Planning, direction and co-ordination of total departmental contribution to specified major transport projects, e.g. Major Airport Needs of Sydney (MANS) Study Provision of the Secretariats for the Australian Transport Advisory Council, Aviation Industry Advisory Council, Marine and Ports Council of Australia, and Transport Industries Advisory Council Development of Policies in association with other Departments where relevant, on Australia's involvement in international organisations and multilateral agreements concerned with transport. Rationalisation and licensing of air transport services Approval of fares, freight rates and timetables for airline operations and administration of financial arrangements in relation to airlines Issue of approvals for export of aircraft and permits for (Question No. 566) import of aircraft and administration of aircraft acquisition policies Negotiation and administration of international air transport agreements and administration of the regulation of international freights and services Formulation of policy in regard to overseas and coastal shipping, including the licensing of vessels to trade on the Australian coast Ensuring the provision of adequate shipping services to meet the needs of the export trade Development of policy on national aspects of development of ports and ship repair facilities Collection of stevedoring and related port statistics Administration and development of policy in relation to the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme Development of policies for the provision of financial assistance for road construction and maintainance for transport planning and research Development of policies in relation to financial assistance to State railway systems, rail standardisation and developmental rail projects; and Administration of grants to the States for the improvement of urban transport systems in capital cities. (b) The functions of the Surface Operations area of my Department are: Provision, administration, operation and maintenance of marine navigational aids Survey and inspection of Australian and foreign ships for compliance with Commonwealth marine legislation and international conventions on safety and pollution Investigation of shipping casualties and oversight of general navigation safety matters Administration of the Register of Australian Ships (Question No. 596) Oversight of the supply of seamen, manning of Australian ships and the qualifications of sea-going personnel Development of maritime communications and traffic operation systems Provision of operational co-ordination of coastal surveillance activities and servicing of the Australian coastal surveillance organisation Provision of a marine search and rescue service including a ship position reporting system Development and administration of policy relating to marine pollution and oversight of the functioning of the National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil Conduct of research into road safety, the development of . vehicle safety, emission standards and uniform traffic codes Provision of advice to the Australian Motor Vehicle Certification Board on the compliance of vehicles with the Australian Design Rules Establishment of policies, formulation of standards, conduct of research and development of educational programs related to road safety Administration of road legislation providing funds to the States for construction and maintenance Evaluation of State road proposals and maintenance of continual liaison with State road authorities on plans and proposals for roads other than National Roads In co-operation with the States development of priorities and implementation of plans for National Roads; (3) Was any request received by him from the Queensland Premier for assistance from the Commonwealth Government for relief aid following that hailstorm'. (4) Was it necessary for the Queensland Premier to declare the area adversely affected by the storm a disaster area, before the Commonwealth Government would provide special assistance. (6) How many declared natural disasters have occurred in each State and Territory in each year since 1940, and in each case what sum has the Commonwealth contributed by way of disaster relief assistance. (7) Is it a fact that Queensland suffers more from natural disasters such as drought, cyclones and floods, than any other State in the Commonwealth. (8) While campaigning in the Electoral Division of MCPherson, or at any other time, has he been informed of the Queensland Premier's recently expressed intention to request Nugan Hand Bank amendments to the disaster relief arrangements between the (Question No. 661) Commonwealth and State Governments. (11) Is it also a fact that when a State Government expends in relief aid on anyone disaster in excess of one tenth of its prescribed base expenditure for natural disasters, the Commonwealth is obliged to contribute towards relief measures on a $3 for $1 basis. (12) How does the Government determine whether grants for relief of personal hardship and distress come within the conditions of the existing disaster arrangements and thereby qualify for Commonwealth reimbursement.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: HIGH COURT BUILDING
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) In the days immediately following the storm, the Commonwealth received, through the Natural Disasters Organisation, regular situation reports from the Queensland State Emergency Service on the damage and the emergency Disaster Relief relief operations, along with requests for Defence Force (Question No. 666) equipment and personnel to assist in the relief operations. Defence Force assistance was provided as requested. Other State Emergency Service reports are prepared for and used by the State and are not necessarily forwarded to the Commonwealth. (3) Yes. Commonwealth assistance was, in any case, available to the State under existing natural disaster relief arrangements for a range of measures. Those applicable to the Brighton hailstorm and other similar occurrances were for relief of personal hardship and distress and for the restoration of public assets and emergency protection and repair work by State, local and semi-government authorities. The Queensland Premier advised the Commonwealth on 22 December 1980 of the implementation of these measures and sought agreement, for the purpose of determining Commonwealth assistance to the State under the arrangements, to variation of limits applicable in individual cases to certain of the measures for relief of personal hardship and distress.l replied in January 1981 indicating the Commonwealth's agreement to the new limits proposed. (4) The declaration of an area as a disaster area is solely a matter for the State Government. Commonwealth assistance for natural disaster relief is not contingent on a State making such a declaration. (5) (a) Standard measures for the relief of personal hardship and distress under the natural disaster relief arrangements comprise: (i) provision of emergency food (ii) provision of emergency clothing (iii) provision of emergency accommodation (iv) essential repairs to secure (v) repair and replacement and personal effects These measures are restricted to people in needy circumstances as a result of a disaster. ( 5) (b) Not in respect of the standard measures. (5) (c) (i), (ii) and (iii) Assistance has been provided spect of claims made by the State Government in relation to these and other disasters. (6) The natural disaster relief arrangements are not designed to provide assistance to basis, but rather to assist a disaster relief assistance provided during a year when it goes beyond the amount originally set to rellect the State's financial capacity. Accordingly, not readily available. Details of Commonwealth assistance to individual States under the ments are available in 1980-81 Budget Paper No.7 (pp 79-80, 139-141) and in earlier issues of this Budget Paper. (7) It is not possible to assess from the information available to the Commonwealth whether Queensland suffers more from natural disasters than any other State. Such an assessment would depend not only also on the extent of damage, both to property and individuals, caused by disasters, not all of which would attract Commonwealth assistance. (8) When the present arrangements were established in 1978, provision was made for regular reviews. On 4 March 1981 I announced that I had written to all State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory proposing that officials consult on a review of the current arrangements to enable consideration at the June 1981 Premiers' Conference. Prior to the announcement of the review, several Premiers, including Mr Bjelke-Petersen, satisfaction with aspects of the arrangements as they affected their States. (9) As indicated in (5) above, the Brighton hailstorm has already attracted Commonwealth assistance in respect of the immediate relief of personal hardship and distress. Expenditure by Queensland on longer-term relief and restoration measures that is in accord with natural disaster relief arrangements would be eligible to attract Commonwealth assistance. Additionally, as was indicated in (1) and (2) above, Defence Force assistance was provided immediately following the storm to meet urgent State requests for manpower and equipment for the emergency relief and restoration operations. (10) and (11) The Commonwealth contributes, on a $3 for $1 basis, to the cost of State and restoration measures (including measures for the relief of personal hardship and distress) in excess of the State's base amount where such expenditures are in respect of a 'major' disaster, A 'major' disaster is, for this purpose, defined as a disaster in respect of which State expenditure on approved measures exceeds one-tenth of the State's base amount. Where a disaster is not a 'major' disaster and/or the State has not exceeded its base amount, State expenditures on approved measures for the relief of personal hardship and distress attract Commonwealth assistance on a $ for $ basis. Further information can be found in 1980-81 Budget Paper No.7 (pages 79-80). (12) The conditions under which Commonwealth assistance in respect of a State's expenditure on the relief of personal hardship and distress is provided, are described in (5) and (11) above. Speaker: Mr LES JOHNSON
Title: HIGH COURT BUILDING
text: the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 12 March 1981: (I) Has the Australian Government received a firm offer of sale of aircraft designed to be used as water-bombers against bushfires; if so, (a) when was the otTer made, (b) what was the name of the company making the offer and (c) what was the proposed contract price. (2) Has he made a response to this offer; if so, what are details.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: HIGH COURT BUILDING
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) (a) An offer was made to sell to the Australian Government two CL21S Water Bomber Aircraft with spares and ground support equipment. (b) The offer was set out in a letter addressed to me dated 4 November 1980 from a Mr J. A. Nicas of Canadair Services Ltd, Montreal, Canada, the manufacturer of the aircraft. (c) The total price in Canadian dollars for the package consisting of both aircraft, spares and equipment, was S11 ,840,000. (2) In my letter ofreply to Mr Nicas I mentioned that the offer had been referred to my colleague, the Minister for Science and Technology for his consideration. Canadair Services the Ltd were aware of the Prime Minister's press release of 22 September 1980 announcing that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation was to conduct a study to evaluate the effectiveness of using aircraft to fight forest and bush fires. I also pointed out that my Department had no expertise in bushfire fighting. Its involvement in the use of civil aircraft for this purpose would primarily be concerned with the prescription of operational safety requirements and airworthiness matters. Since referring the matter to my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology, no further approaches have been made to my Department concerning the sale of these aircraft.
